review_text:
An Inspiring Movie: Hello Love Goodbye, despite being a largely feel-good film, did not shy away from the harsh realities that its OFW audience experiences. Despite being upfront with the struggles of an OFW, it still serves as a gentle, hopeful reminder for our modern day heroes to not forget to choose themselves. To not forget that they can allow themselves to dream, to love, and most of all, to be human. It show that love can wait but our dreams it knock once like opportunity grab it once it came in your or our life.

Kathryn Bernardo portrays Joy's exhaustion, anger and resolution so potently without much words. It all comes out in the way her lids look heavy from a two-hour sleep; how her shoulders slump as she grapples with the thought of her agonizingly routine life. We see it in her quiet moments in the night when she can catch a few minutes just to stare blankly at the wall. The depiction felt authentic and tugs at your heartstrings, Joy is the symbol of women with dream. And also her leading man this is a more mature role for Alden as well, and the material lets him show a deeper side to his acting chops. His character's personal story carried as much weight as the romance, and in Ethan's vulnerable moments, we see Alden as a dramatic actor, and not just a tutti-frutti leading man. That's not to say that he didn't play the charismatic boyfriend role well, though. The kilig factor we as always cranked up to high, thanks also to his and Kathryn's organic chemistry.

The most unforgettable scene in this movie when Ethan and Joy decided to leave each other to continue their dream and when Ethan said "will you give the rest of your time with me in Hong Kong? ". Those line make me sad and overwhelmed because even they know that they leave each other they choose to understand and make those little time to make memorable, they choose to spent those time to be happy. This movie make us inspired that life is like a photography, we developed from negative.

Love is About Letting Go...Not Sacrifice: I've seen a few of Kathryn Bernardo's films, and I believe she turned in the performance of her life. She stepped away from the typical romantic-comedies (many of which are actually quite good), and challenged herself to take on the role of a much deeper and much more complex character in Joy.

I have always marveled--and not in a good way--of how people tend to use others; even people they love; even members of their own families. Of course, children are usually guilted into it. In short, it's a parent's way of saying, "I suffered, and so now you must suffer too. Why? Because it's how families work."

As stated in other reviews, I am an ESL teacher. I've lived and worked in South Korea, China, and Taiwan. I know quite a bit about how Asian parents tend to treat their kids. Of course, it's not all bad. You'll scarcely find parents who are more dedicated to teaching their children about discipline and hard-work. The large contrast between them and western parents, is that western parents tend to allow their kids to do whatever they want. They're spoiled beyond belief. What is needed is a balance.

As the eldest daughter, Joy is in Hong Kong working several jobs in order to keep herself alive as well as sending money back home to her family in the Phillippines. She has a nursing degree. Her dream is to go to Canada to pursue what she loves. Of course, she meets and falls in love with Ethan, a young man who is also from the Phillippines, who is trying to support his family as well, after a disastrous relationship that nearly cost him everything.

Ethan, of course, is hoping that Joy will decide to stay in Hong Kong, and not go to Canada. This is when the film really grabs the viewer to see what Joy will decide to do.

Love is not about sacrifice for someone else. Sacrifice is about losing something, and love is never about loss. It's always about who you are. In all her wisdom, Joy has to explain this to Ethan as well as outlining the consequences of not pursuing her dream. Fortunately, Ethan finally gets it and is able to do what only love can do: let go. As soon as you try to hold onto it, love ceases to be love.

Filmed in Hong Kong, we're giving a stark and not-so-pleasing depiction of life for many immigrants struggling to survive. Some can do it. Some can't. In the end, you can only truly look after yourself and not lose sight of your own dreams. Of course, the world, and even your own family will throw every reason at you to NOT pursue your dreams. If you give in, you have no one to blame but yourself. If you forge ahead, then you have gained more profound wisdom about life than what most people can only dream about.

My only complaint of the film was that the chemistry between Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards was not what it should have been. And because of this, the film loses a bit of its heart and depth. I'd say it was pretty obvious that Kathryn Bernardo did not want to do any kissing scenes with Alden due to her love and respect for her boyfriend, Daniel Padilla. The only kiss we see is one on her forehead in the dark. Can you imagine the lack of depth in a film like Titanic if Jack and Rose only held hands and never shared a kiss? I couldn't help but wonder how much more powerful the film would have been if another actress had performed in the role, or if Padilla himself hadn't turned the role down (which I read that he had).

Still, this is a memorable film that challenges everyone to go after their dreams and let nothing and no one stand in your way.

What a nice surprise of a movie...: Right, well I didn't really know what I was getting into here when I sat down to watch the 2019 Tagalog movie that was filmed in Hong Kong. Initially I thought it was a Chinese movie, but upon seeing the names of the cast, I looked on IMDb and saw that it was a Tagalog (Philippines) movie and not a Cantonese (Hong Kong) movie. And given my fascination with Asian movie, of course I sat down to watch "Hello, Love, Goodbye".

And I must definitely say that writers Carmi Raymundo, Cathy Garcia-Molina and Ronalisa A. Co came up with a rather enthralling storyline; one that definitely provided as much of entertainment and enjoyment, as it was a movie that was very watchable and likeable.

The storyline is one that easily sways away the audience, because it is wholehearted and nicely told storyline. And milling about in the storyline are some nicely detailed and interesting characters. So a big thumbs up to the writers on this accomplishment.

I will say that the acting in the movie was good. Now, I am not overly familiar with Tagalog cinema, but my wife told me that there were some rather famous Tagalog actresses and actors in the movie. Nevertheless, I think the acting performances were spot on.

At the same time, with providing a good story and good entertainment, "Hello, Love, Goodbye" really brought me back to my four years of living and working in Hong Kong. This movie stoked so many memories and definitely spurred a desire to return to Hong Kong to revisit that fabulous place.

If you like romantic movies, then I strongly believe that the 2019 movie "Hello, Love, Goodbye" from director Cathy Garcia-Molina is a movie that you will thoroughly enjoy. I was more than genuinely entertained by this movie, and it is a movie that I can warmly recommend you sit down to watch.

My rating of "Hello, Love, Goodbye" lands on a well-deserved seven out of ten stars.

Hello, Love, no Goodbyes.: Being the highest-grossing Philippine movie thus far, I hope you don't mind if I came into watching this with high expectations. Still I was skeptic because the assumption was it will be another one of those formulaic Star Cinema movie starring Kathryn Bernardo, directed by Cathy Molina-Garcia, set in an international location, usual love story but with a twist: we get a new boy this time in the form of Alden Richards. For the most part I was right, it was all you could ever expect from the same group that gave us the highest-grossing movie the year before, 'How's of Us.' Amidst it's shortcomings, 'Hello, Love, Goodbye' is a pleasant surprise for a movie who's theme has been done a million times. Part of it's success can be attributed to showing us the reality of our hardworking domestic helpers in Hong Kong (which the OFW community all over the world related and responded to) and it did not give us the usual ending we are used to, which makes a sequel possible seeing as all three already expressed interest in doing.

The story was well-written for the most part and my favorite was the start of the movie. It was a different approach, fast-paced and intriguing. While at some point it had to slow down to become what it really was meant to be in the first place, a typical Pinoy love story, at least it introduced something new to the audience that can be the new norm in the future. Acting-wise, Kathryn and Alden both delivered but both lacked maturity which I'm hoping can be improved on once the sequel rolls around. There were exchanges that fell flat because either a) it was poorly-written or b) both did not have the capacity to deliver them with the emotions needed. It took a while for their chemistry to kick in, possibly a result of being pigeonholed in their respective love teams for a long time. Kathryn can act, but she has certain mannerisms when she deliver some of her lines that breaks my concentration from her acting. I'm still getting rich girl even though she's supposed to be covered in filth from hiding under a pile of garbage bags. Alden still comes from the John Lloyd Cruz school for acting, but as soon as he develops his own signature he should be destined for greater things. The supporting cast did what was required of them, with Maxine Medina and Jameson Blake as highlights.

There's always the burden of asking whether this is the movie that will propel Philippine cinema back to it's old glory. Obviously this is not it, but delightfully it's not a step back as well. Knowing this specific tandem and formula works, hopefully everyone involved will be more keen on wanting to elevate the viewing experience the second time around. I keep harping on this because I honestly believe it has the potential to become even more special than what they've already done here.

Truly amazing: This is so far, the best Filipino movie of 2019. I really love the story, which shows a lot about the lives of Filipino workers in Hong Kong. It is not like any other of those Filipino rom-com, and drama movies you've seen before. This will make you laugh out loud a lot and cry hard.

For me this is Cathy Garcia-Molina's best movie. Kathryn and Alden really shines in this, great acting by the whole cast. It also has great shots, cinematography and soundtrack so it is a must watch!

Mature and bold love story: The two stars from the two different stations hit it off with good chemistry in this mature love story. Although the story is as typical as any Filipino love/romance movie could be, I like the fact that the writer and director went for the bold path of ending the movie with "goodbye", instead of coming up with an epilogue that let the two lovers meet again in some future. The two lead stars are engaging enough for you to care what happens to them in the end but there are some parts where it could drag. Still, I can understand the clamor when this movie came out in 2019.

THE BEST FILIPINO MOVIE EVER: This is the best pinoy movie ever. The characters are superb. Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards performance was the best. There is no boring moments in the movie. It's a must watch for everyone. Kathryn Bernardo played the role of Joy a Filipino worker in Hong Kong who is struggling and doing odd jobs to take care of her family. On the other hand Alden Richards played the role of Ethan a funny and unserious bartender who later crossed path with Joy and the story of their undying love begins. The story is not just another pinoy love story. It's a story that shows the struggle of all OFW . I was touched and move by the acting of Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards. They made it possible for me to relate with the movie. I'm not a Filipino but I was able to get every piece of the movie because of their wonderful onscreen chemistry. Kudos to the cast and crew. Good job Director Molina. I wouldn't mind to travel again for the part 2 of this movie. It's worth my time and my money. More movies for this duos please. I would always travel with my family to watch their movie onscreen. More movies for Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards please. They've won my heart.

WASTE OF TIME AND MONEY!: I was excited to watch the film due to the hype and some of my friends posting about it on social media however, I was very disappointed after watching the film as the acting from the lead actors including supporting cast appeared quite scripted and very awkward. Kathryn & Alden seemed too rehearsed and some of their co-actors were really annoying. The story was predictable and recycled from previous films. Only thing I appreciate was the cinematography and soundtrack. Save your money and just watch this on netflix or cinema one when it airs.

A simple mirror: This is another cheese pinoy movie, but base in real life, that is the point, at the end family is not the principal role, a twisted end, a lot of lacrimogen bomb, good for the family but pinoy is the new korean drama
Great Movie: Its an eye opener to some of the facing problems of OFW

Time Must Start Again  °7.7° °VG ° %: Timing in life is everything; so the adage goes. In Hong Kong, time is GLD. As long as you move you'll live. Once you stop you'll starve. Over 200,000 Filipinos work in Hong Kong. It's most common to have a 2-yr domestic helper contract as Filipinos are not allowed to do anything else - unless they manage to become a citizen. Therefore, when Joy loses her job because her employers can no longer pay her, she takes an illegal waitressing job. The cops, inevitably, will come by to check IDs. When Joy sees them, she busts a move and runs. She ends up running right into the handsome bartender and busts another move. She uses him as camouflage to hide from the po-po. Cops rarely bother a couple snogging in the alleyway, afterall. It's done so often in movies you might think that they would start checking, even if a duo is rounding first and headed for second, but it always seems to work.

The Filipino community in Hong Kong is small. Everyone is within 1° of separation, but it's large enough to support a Filipino radio station. (They have a nifty microeconomic system in place as well.) Joy thinks she got away scott-free only to wake up the next morning to a radio announcement about her! Ethan, the bartender, is looking for Joy so that she can return the kiss that she stole from him! Joy's friends go insane.

HLG is about what decent, but poor, people must do to survive: It is all about hard choices. It is also about the nature of love. Joy & Ethan. Ethan + Joy. She resists him, but she can't for long. The problem is that she's leaving. She's definitely leaving. She has a nursing degree that she can't use in Hong Kong. She's going to be a nurse in Canada. That's her dream, and nthing's going to change her mind. Nt a thing/budkis/pistza/larkaflark/nuffink/jack squat/NATTY. Joy is no wimp. She has a will of iron. She warns Ethan to not get attached. Yet they allow themselves to fall in love. Every day they push the knife in a little deeper.

Their story is sweet and these protags are likable. He says he can handle it and he won't get in her way, but as that  approaches the pressure ratchets up. Because, 'when you love, it's all or nothing. If you hold back, then why love it all?' Ethan has a point. 'There are questions inside of me that only I can answer,' Joy insists. Joy has goals, a mission, and an ironclad agenda. She will not be swayed. Not now.

LVE. What does it look like? To Ethan it's: "If you loved me enough you would stay."  To Joy it's: "If you loved me enough you would want me to go." Later, Joy asks the universe: "When a woman gives too much of herself, she's stupid, but when she prioritizes herself, she's bad. Where do we need to place ourselves? Is love only expressed through sacrifice?" Why so often, indeed, does every option, for women especially, seem irreconcilable? Love can teeter from selfish to selfless. Perhaps love always starts down in the selfish zone, but the more we sincerely love someone, the more selfless we should become. Leaving the shallow end and diving down deeper should elevate our love higher. If not, we must question how much in  we are or how selfish we actually are. A young person should never be expected to throw away h/h future for a relationship, particularly a relatively new one. Talk about creating a debt for regret - No sane person would endorse that. Joy agonizes over this unexpected timeout from the race she's been running. Either option is valid. Her choice is hers alone. HLG tells young girls that their personal development and future is every bit as important as love.

Befitting a modest budget, most of the filming is on the street or in contained spaces. There's a couple of wow shots. They take a day off to go up into the mountains. On a cliff looking down on the city, the buildings are uniformly white. While they look like bad dental work there's also an ethereal beauty to the vista. The effect is otherworldly.

HLG is a 118 minute, 2019 release that is rated 8.2 on MDL. Overall, this is a well put together production. The writing, directing and acting all blend to make a great product with few flaws. This is a Filipino production and I am looking forward to seeing more of their works. I've seen 2 Hong Kong productions, The Defected-8.2 and Hong Kong West Side Stories(7.5). Both of them are good but also dark, edgy, sad, and a display of the worst elements of humanity. The group that is the most downtrodden in Hong Kong seems to have a brighter outlook. Between the 3 productions, one wouldn't think it's the same place. HLG is well worth the time to get a peek at life in Hong Kong from the view of the hard working, overlooked Filipino community. We have alot to be thankful for.

QUOTE

Choice is only for the rich.

 IMHO

78 72 79 70 67 71 70 30 /78 23 47 30 49 20 45 0 70

Age 12+ Adult situations kissing - mild. Rated PG: Parental Guidance Suggested

Re-? Not opposed.

best filipino love story movie: This movie is almost 90% accurate when it comes to portraying ofw life in china. acting is very good and I never expected that kath and alden would have a good chemistry.

not good not bad: Another Kathryn same ol' tone of character film! I wish that her writers and directors would gave her something different worthy of famas or urian award, she deserves it, it was just the material that always failed her.

The story could have been very good to tell, but it was the storytelling that seems to be ordinary and safe... it could have been pushed a little bit more.

but at the end of the day, it makes you feel something and that is what Filipino films are good at

Superb acting and story: Kathryn and Alden gave justice to their characters. You'll forget that these are actors just portraing roles because they portrayed their characters so well! The chemistry between these two is overflowing! These movie is not just a love story, it's a life story. It tells you the life of Overseas Filipino Worker abroad, the struggle that they have to go through to achieve their goals for themselves and thier family.

Hello, Love, Goodbye: Unexpected chemistry of Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards. They successfully portrayed their characters. The plot of the story is great and we want more! Great job Team HLG! Part2 please!!!

Nice.: Pretty great. Finally, no cheesy cliché Filipino romance in here. It's a great start for hollywood-esque films  It even has lessons like remember to care for your family and how to love someone purely. How much OFWs work hard just to provide for their family and how other people should appreciate that. The best one is 'I love you but this time, I love myself more.' :)

What the world needs: Real emotion, it gives you a glimpse of what its like to be an ofw worker, more so being a domestic helper.

Teaching one that inorder for you to love others, you need to love yourself first. You need to choose your own happiness

Alden Richards' character, Ethan, is pushy, creepy and problematic.: Ethan will continue sending friend requests even if Joy declined several times already. He will make the radio station talk about Joy in public without her permission. He will use another phone to text Joy anonymously. He will act like a police even if Joy is weeping out of fear. He will squeeze through inside a small room knowing that Joy will be uncomfortable. He will continually send "Need a friend today?" text messages even if Joy has rejected it so many times. I don't know how a Filipino girl reacts to such moves, but if people consider this as "nakakakilig," there's a problem.

'Hello, Love, Goodbye' is at its best when it tells the story of Kathryn Bernardo's character, Joy. In some ways, the film manages to outdo similar mainstream Filipino romance films because of Kathryn Bernardo's stunning performance and the earnest depiction of OFWs. Bernardo, whose acting holds the film together when it was falling apart, effectively evokes a palpable sense of weariness, discontent, and eagerness to alleviate Joy's situation. Actually, I can do without the 'La La Land' love story if the social commentary was strengthened and expounded more. In a similar vein with 'Sunday Beauty Queen,' the film resonates with Filipinos because of its sensible portrayal of what it is like to work abroad in a job you are overqualified in.

But Cathy Garcia-Molina's picture falls apart as the annoying, melodramatic score continues to play in the background, tackier drone shots are added, and more forced, "hugot" dialogues are delivered by the leads. Sure, this is how cliché-ridden mainstream Filipino romance plays out. But how I wish we get movies that transcend this generic romantic stratagem. 'Hello, Love, Goodbye' fails to offer something new to romance movies as an art form, which is disappointing since the OFW story and Joy's arc have so much potential.

BEST OF 2019: This is by far the first movie of Alden Richards that I watched. At first, it was just an attempt to like the tandem of Kath and Alden but it turned out to be an affirmation of their chemistry. I was moved and even shed some tears even in scenes where not much is expected. Simple conversations that will make you fall into tears. Very touching movie. It's actually about Love in general and that includes Love of Family.

It was the most best movie of Alden and Kathryn i ever watched: This not just a love story..it was more than a love story.. its story of dreams that we need to see how far we can go and nothing can stop us even love. And i salute all Filipinos who works hard and conquered other countries for their families. WE ABSOLUTELY NEED A SECOND PART IN THIS ONE. I don't really into in Filipino movies it was my first local movie i watched in 2019.

Much Love: I would love to watch this over and over again. i Love the film all in general. i was so speechless, so please help your self to witness this Movie. it's not your typical love story but it was a real life of an ofw that working hard.

Not your ordinary love story. A story highlighting selfless love and sacrifice: Breathe of freshness on screen, we've been served with a platter of good offering, AR's gentleman antics and KB's toughness and complexity complements each other's character just right, a movie that highlights the life,pain and sufferings of filipino working abroad especially Hongkong an eye opener about the common misconceptions about the life of our modern day heroes the brave ofws. Another masterpiece from direct Cathy Garcia Molina for mixing out the reality of life abroad, stories of risk-takers the dreamers sacrifice & selfless love.

The Story Has Potential - The Film Failed to Deliver: As far as the film's story goes, it has so much potential. It depicts a few of the many instances of what OFWs experience while working abroad. But the way Cathy Garcia-Molina presented the story was too mediocre.

Their choice to cast Alden and Kathryn was bad. There isn't any chemistry between them. The chemistry happened between the viewers and Alden/Kathryn, but not between the characters themselves.

Alden's character was unrefined. His acting was subpar. His smile is problematic. Instead of conveying something that relates to being hurt or having a struggle, it becomes out of place and sometimes creepy.

The camera shots were out of place. It felt like the production team were trying to show off their drone shots even when it would have been better to just use a simple wide shot. Close-ups were not utilized properly.

The script contained the typical "hugot" lines. At the same time, the film contained at least 30 minutes of pure exposition. It became a film of telling rather than showing.

I haven't talked about the problems with the other casts. But overall, the film was purely a waste of time. I would have felt better if I just watched the film "Anak" with the other OFWs in one of the film's scenes.

Unexpectedly Real!: Oh they went deeeeeppp.

This isnt just one of those sappy romance stories, no, it covers real-life topics (i assume) about Filipinos foreign workers, immigration etc. I gotta admit that i never really think twice about these things but this movie makes me feel the pain! We just gotta be grateful of choices we have in life - some people have it harder.

Now, Kathryn (Joy) is such an amazing actress! I can almost relate to everything shes going through in the movie. And oh, prepare tissues cause youre gonna need em.

P/s: Low-key Hong Kong Tourism ad done right. lol

A Movie With A Heart: Hello Goodbye Love. What a beautifully made movie, what a wonderful message for the millennials. Great story by Ms. Carmi Raymundo, great directing by Cathy Garcia-Molina, great acting by both main actors, Ms. Kathryn Bernardo and Mr. Alden Richards as well as the supporting actors. The movie focuses on the life of Joy, a Filipino nurse-graduate who works instead as a DH (Domestic Helper) in Hong Kong. The crux of the film shows how OFWs (Overseas Filipino Worker) live in other countries. For me, the love story between the characters was secondary but it was the right touch to bind things together. Kathryn is most beautiful bare-faced and delivers a great performance. A must-see movie. 10/10

A Filipino movie that you should watch: This is by far the best Filipino movie of 2019. And one of the best of all time. There's no waste or boring moment. This movie sets the new benchmark for Filipino movie. A must watch and highly recommended.

It's Unique by itself, Highly recommended! A must watch film!: It's Unique by itself, Highly recommended! A must watch film! Alden (Ethan) and Kathryn (Joy) brings spice to a good story! I can tell that its a masterpiece! Love the Movie!

PS. Part 2 please
Boring: The movie is a bit boring, a let-down. Too many scenes with nothing happening and boring dialogue. Ain't diggin this shiz.

Worth-watching, good story: Not a fan of the 2 lead actors, but I can say that they did a good job portraying the characters in this movie. Cinematography is good! The 2 leads have chemistry despite them not being paired at all before. However, they sound a bit awkward when delivering lines in english language. The story, most especially the ending part, makes it worth-watching. Good overall and probably the best Filipino movie among the others during that time, however, it is similar to the other mainstream Filipino movies. It would be better if the movie would be made subtle the way indie movies do.
Please do the part 2: Falling in love with the whole story and the actor. Mixed feelings but i need the second please do the part 2 please don't stop making great story like this.

A Must Watch Movie!: I highly recommend this movie to everyone. This is not your ordinary rom-com movie that will just give you smile and love. This is a realistic movie where you'll see the life of a Filipino OFW in Hongkong- the sacrifices and dreams for the family. But love will always come at the least expected time. Kathryn Bernardo- never failed me to amaze on her acting skills. She always devote herself into the character and put amazing life onto it. I must say that I'm a fan. Alden Richards on the other hand surprises me on his hotness throughout the whole movie. These two characters made my heart cry and leaving me to re-watch again the movie. That feeling you have when you finish an amazing movie that you don't want it to end. Director Cathy is a genius on her craft. She knows how to perfectly put drama, romance and comedy into a single movie! Everyone must watch this movie! This movie will teach or remind us to- love yourself, love your family, follow your dreams, live your life to the fullest until you have time, true love will set you free, and the list goes on!

HONEST REVIEW: Nothing special about the movie's plot except the best performance from Kathryn and Alden: Maybe because I couldn't relate to the movie. But Kathryn and Alden was so great they make the ordinary story extraordinary! And don't forget the kilig factor Alden brought up on some scenes. Overall, not a waste of money.

HONEST Review. Why 5?: Lets start with how great Kathryn's acting is. As expected from her The Hows of Us piece. Alden did OK. Wasn't expecting much but it was a solid performance. However his acting reminds me of John Lloyd. And if you act like someone else's then you should give justice to it or do better. But in this movie it's neither. Then again a solid one. Now, the lines. They are trying to squeeze the "hugots" absolutely anywhere they want in the film. And it's absolutely out of timing! The lines are so bad that I can say I can write that. Yeah its that bad. The songs doesnt go well with the scenes which completely ruined the greatness of the song. They could have done it better. Cinematography is so bad, its like you're watching a TV series. Go watch it again, you'll see the same style of focus and switch to subject over and over again. There are many scenes that could've shot with them both in the frame to show their emotions at the same time. It was like Action! And Cut! Next line! The style of shots just changed in about 10-15mins remaining in the film. It looked like they realized it and hired someone else. And my 11 yr old daughter even agreed how bad the shots are. Compare this with Tadhana, 100 na Tula, Kita Kita, The Day After Valentines, Never Not Love You, and #WalangForever. If you havent seen these, go watch them and thank me later. 5 is because of Kathryn.

Wow!!! Just wow!!!: In what may be Cathy Garcia Molina's best movie to date, this movie overcomes the banal and stereotypical nuances pinoy romcoms are known for. In fact the apparent filipino diaspora is the true backdrop of this movie. The dissolution of every OFW workers success or possible demise. The ensuing love story merely serves as extravagance but will eventually turn complimentary to the already palatable storyline of Kathryn Bernardo's plight as a struggling domestic helper torn between the choice of staying in Hongkong to be with the man she loves (Alden Richards) and fulfilling her destiny to be a succesful nurse in Canada. Both characters are vibrant and played to a T by the two lead actors. Not really a fan of Alden Richards, one may surmise that he was directed exceptionally well for this or was incidentally a victim of writing mediocrity in previous films. But that stockroom scene is just plain fun and genius. The chemistry between the two characters made apparent by screams of excitement from my neighboring seat as the pair locked eyes for the first time. Forget about the common adequacy pinoy films are usually associated with. We may suck in action and sci-fi movies but we can definitely make quality films in other genres. Like this one. Baduy na kung baduy, but this is a movie you should watch. Again, this is not a paid ad. Lol!
Nice love story with great story lines: My first time watching filipina romantic love story & the storyline was pretty engaging. It keeps you watching all the way. Great acting and scenes as well
Great movie: Great acting skills of Alden, warms the heart despite struggles working abroad

It's not hollywood, but for a pinoy style movie , this is ver good!: After watching the movie, i just have love everything about it : the feeling of missing the characters after the movie ended . Here's my thought: 1. Goodvibes, inside the cinema, it is so nice to hear people having mixed emotions throughout the entire movie, nakakakilig, nakakatawa, nakakaiyak . It's not heavy , just simple. 2. Kathryn's voice is just perfect for her role. She has a straight face but she managed to give expressions that justifies every line she says, thru her eyes. You will love her more in this movie. 3. Alden has an expressive face, can portray a sad eyes and happy smile at the same time. With that expressive face, I was amazed that he made me smile and laugh with those supposedly cheesy lines of the script. I did not expect that he is this good. He actually can shift from happy to sad to serious without you noticing the transition. Plus he is so manly and handsome. Many women inside the cinema were so 'kilig' everytime his face shows up especially upclose. 3. The supporting cast will give you a break to the story of joy and ethan, they are very funny! I meant, just their presence adds excitement. They are the ones who completed the movie. 4. Good choice of names of the lead actors. Joy is a name that is nice to hear from Alden's voice. Ethan could be alden's alternative name in real life, it suits him well . And Mary dale is maymay's real name, very filipino and youthful name for her character. 5. Great chemistry, Ethan's arms looks so comfy everytime he hugs Joy. When they look at each other in the eyes, it's genuine. Alden's bubbly voice and Joy's serious voice are blending nicely that is why just them sitting and talking brings "kilig". 5. You can see hongkong itself, even in just a glimpse you can see the unity of filipinos. Being an ofw is hard but having to see a community of filipino around you brings comfort and home. 6. Some parts are like music videos, maybe because the music is so good to hear in those hongkong buildings in the background. 7. Direk cathy is really exeptional. She will bring out the best in all actors. She choses the best on everything. 7. The movie itself tells different stories in just 2 hours. All stories are true to life, but hopeful . All stories are aspiring to have a better life and chasing happiness. In order to chase happiness, you should make sacrifices, but making sacrifices is not sad at all . It is a challenge and part if the process. The whole movie is not korean or hollywood, but filipino. Like any other movies, it is not perfect. There is always room for improvement. But that improvement, we should make movies more like filipino style. It is very simple actually but filipinos are loving it because it is very light, its for family bonding. You wont feel awkward watching it with your grandparents. I gave it 10 over 10 because i cant get over it.

personal bakstori: napanood ko 'to nang d maayos dati sa tv kasama pa ata mga relatives ko and everybody was talking like nasa bg lng tlg sha yung typical na pag may bisita d nakafocus sa tv pang background noise lang tas titingin lng from time 2 time not full focus LMAO pero i remember it catching my attention and i remember telling myself na gusto ko siya mapanood properly someday well that someday came HAHAHAreal review starts here goods naman sha for me tbh ang galing ng acting omfgggggggg stellar performance(s)! kumabog talaga shet kathrynnnnnn ipinakita mo talaga kung sino ka! slay! i remember may nadaanan akong interview niya saying how hard everything was for her shooting this but it really shows how everything paid off galing niya dito sobra, ito rin ata first big thing na wala ung  so glad for that decision na iba ung nagplay opposite her anyway lov the side characs na besties too super natural kaya what i can say about this movie is the best thing about it are the performances talaga iba pagkakadeliver nila and appreciate ko rin naman how it showcase ung buhay ng mga kababayan natin and presents conflicts not just with work but also with family and self and dreams maraming natouch na topics tong film na 'to dialouge medyo naooff minsan and may mga questionable talaga na sinabi at actions ang mga characters (lalo na kay alden BWAHAHAH) tho i think it makes it more realistic and humanizes the characters even more I'm just so glad with how they wrote kath's character din and how she stood her ground yas queeen!! and may mga binatong linya na kabog din naman talaga couple of gag worthy quotes pero minsan sumosobra na it doesnt sound authentic na ung flow HAHAHA pero saks lng kaya kahit pumapalya sa mga certain areas andon parin yung tatak pinoy + the humor lmao so i appreciate it and most of all i actually enjoyed it so its worth the watch and my time kahit d siya fully formed story and may mga shallow (& problematic) areas talaga I'll let this one slide bc enjoyable paren tbh kita ko bakit patok sa "mainstream".

Ang choice, para lang sa may peraSobrang unfair ng mundo kay Joy. Hindi naman siya nagkulang. Sa katunayan sumobra pa nga. Sa pagmamahal, pag-alala, pagtatrabaho, at marami pang iba. Pero mapait pa rin ang mundo sa kanya. At lahat ng 'yon naranasan niya kasi wala siyang pera. Ang sad nung reflection ng reality ng buhay sa Pilipinas. Na para bang hindi na option ang migrasyon kundi isang daan na kailangan mong gawin para umangat sa buhay. All throughout the film, walang balak bumalik si Joy sa Pilipinas. Wala siyang balak maghirap nang sobra. Enter Ethan. Ang heartbreaking lang nung fact na he had to experience the same experience twice. Buti na lang he was matured enough the second time.Putek graduate ako ng college, anong ginagawa ko naglilinis ng inidoro?Dito ako umiyak eh HAHAHAHA. Joy is full of dreams. Mataas ang pangarap niya pero willing siya mag settle sa kung anong pwede niyang magawa. Ang sakit lang na kahit maraming propesiyonal sa Pilipinas, mas marami pa ring pipiling mangibang bansa kahit hindi akma sa kursong tinapos at sana'y pina practice nila. Joy and Ethan finding solace with each other feels natural. Na para bang they meant to find each other. Overall, the film is really good. I remembered crying the same amount as the first time I watched this. On different parts lang. Lol

Ang pelikulang Hello, Love, Goodbye ay isang nakakaantig na kwento tungkol sa pag-ibig at mga sakripisyong ginawa para sa mga pangarap. Ang paggamit ng Filipino sa mga emosyonal na eksena ay kapansin-pansin sa pelikulang ito, na nagbigay ng mas malalim na koneksyon sa mga manonood. Ang mga linya ay natural at totoo, kaya ang mga emosyon ng mga karakter ay higit na nadarama. Gayunpaman, may ilang bahagi kung saan ang mga diyalogo ay may halong Ingles, na bagama't nagbibigay ng makabagong tono, ay nakakabawas sa lalim ng mensahe sa wikang Filipino. Sa aking palagay, maganda pa rin ang paggamit ng Filipino sa pelikulang ito dahil ito ay nagpapakita ng ating wika na nagpapahayag ng tunay na damdamin at karanasan. Para lalo pang pagbutihin, makabubuting bigyang pansin ang paggamit ng mas malalim at mas masining na mga salita sa Filipino upang mas maipakita ang yaman at kagandahan ng ating sariling wika.

i really love how they’ve shown the lives of the ofws — their sacrifices, silent battles, and the longing that comes with being miles away from home. one of the main reasons why i chose this as the film subject for my discourse analysis in grade 11.but above all, they’ve shown us a story about choosing yourself — and all that you have to go through to do that. and joy was such a great protagonist for this because how can you love someone so much, and still have to let them go to choose yourself? some might take it as a selfish decision, when in reality, it is not. all her life, she had to put others first before herself, giving up and sacrificing things for people. but when the time came that she finally decided to choose herself, she wasn’t being selfish — she was finally being free. i admire her so much for having the courage to leave, to allow herself to grow and dream.and ethan? sometimes, love alone can never be enough. it’s a hard pill to swallow, but it’s the truth — the reality that not all the love in the world can save us. joy was never lacking in reminding him that she’s going to leave. she never made false promises, never painted a forever she couldn’t give. from the beginning, she was clear that she’s not open to commitments, clear that she’s leaving. it was he who pushed himself into her life, even when she kept on pushing him away. i know that ethan just hoped — it’s not a bad thing — but sometimes, hope blinds us from the truth we already know, making her choose between the dream she’s been working hard for and the love she never expected to find.so yup, joy, tama ka sa sinabi mong, “kung mahal mo ’ko, bakit pinapapili mo ako?” dahil ang pag-ibig ay dapat na mapagpalaya, hindi isang pakikibaka. at kailan man ay hindi magiging masama ang piliin ang sarili.at sana, makahanap tayong lahat ng taong hindi tayo papipiliin tulad ni ethan :)

Not the most life altering piece of cinema but definitely the most modern Filipino movie that I'm proud of so far.RIP to kathniel but also not because Kathryn Bernardo (and these other actors) deserve to have their spotlight and be taken srsly as actors instead of being forced into a loveteam from an early age. Still loved their movies together but this was definitely a huge risk in the Filipino entertainment industry and I’m glad they delivered. Obviously still has its fair share of red flag romanticism for the leading man but as ALWAYSSSSSS the Filipina baddie carries. But just knowing how the usual Filipino rom coms go, this was already breaking tradition, while still managing to deliver the kilig factors. I LOVE that the ending is up to interpretation, and Kathryn still pursues her career as a nurse. VERY bold choices against the usual Filipino movie plot lines. It’s a good love story, the chemistry is there, and also love how it mixes in the harsh realities of working abroad and the hard-working Filipino spirit. THEY WERE IN HONG KONG THOUGH,, so the shots could have been way prettier cinematically. But props to the director and the casting, Kathryn Bernardo always has my heart and I can’t wait to see her in more movies. Alden is alright too  ** I’m just pretending the sequel doesn’t exist. **

this movie got its corny moments, but still a heartfelt and tearjerking movie.beyond the romance, the dilemmas and struggles of OFWs were given justice in this movie, which makes watching it truly worthwhile. yung experiences and sentiments ng mga characters, na ipinakita ng movie felt honest and deeply resonant. like grabe daming baon na kwento at aral.hindi ko mapigilan maging emotional on that scene—when Joy came across with his nurse classmate who's out for vacation. as they caught up on each other’s life status, I can't help but sob for Joy. life can be unfair sometimes.

This movie shows the reality of Filipinos who move to another country to work for the sole purpose of supporting their families back in the Philippines. I personally cannot relate, but I know my parents have experienced this and I can understand them a bit better now. Like all the Filipino movies I've seen lately, they all have HEART, and this movie is no different. - J

This movie is literally for every eldest daughter who's "ate ng bayan sa umaga, breadwinner sa gabi, tapos sa love life...?" Waley.  Hong Kong never looked this emotionally exhausting. OFW stories are usually soaked in sacrifice, pero this one hits you with that emotional labor type of heartbreak—the kind that doesn't end with "kami pa rin sa huli," but more like, "minahal kita... at 'yun na 'yun."Alden Richards? Shocking. As in, shookt ako. He brought soft boy energy with a sprinkle of “gusto kita, pero hindi kita pipilitin.” Kathryn? Ma’am. Ma’am??? She ATE. That breakdown scene? The way she cried like her lungs were collapsing from every missed dream? Oscar-worthy sa puso ng bawat umuwing pagod na ate.Real talk:This isn’t about “will they end up together?” It’s about choosing yourself, even when it hurts like hell.Sometimes love says goodbye.Sometimes goodbye is love.And sometimes… you cry in the tricycle ride home while pretending your eyes are just “napuwing lang.” Para sa mga nagmahal, nasaktan, pero hindi iniwan ang sarili. At para sa mga nagtatrabaho para sa pamilya, kahit pagod na pagod na.You’re the real main character.

Realistic. Slow-burning. Melancholic.Maganda yung pagkakaexecute nung story. OFW story siya pero hindi yung typical story. Ang galing ni Kathyrn dito. Buti na lang hindi siya nastuck sa love team niya with Daniel. Mas lumabas yung galing niya sa pagacting and sa pagportray niya sa character. Super natural lang nung acting niya. Ang galing din ni Alden. Pumantay talaga siya sa acting ni Kathryn. Slow paced siya pero hindi yung nakakaboring kasi nabuibuild up yung emotion hanggang climax.Super daming iconic lines. Iba talaga si Direk Cathy. Maganda kasi nahighlight yung hardship ng isang OFW. Pinakita rin kung gaano kalakas and katapang ang isang babae. Nagustuhan ko siya kasi hindi siya yung typical romance movie na happily ever after. Super realistic lang nung ending especially for a person na mas uunahin ang pamilya kaysa sa sariling kaligayahan. Minsan yung tunay na love ay yung handang magparaya. Masakit pero kailangan.

Peak Filipino Hugot-core bittersweet film, or maybe it's because I am so spoiled with Wong Kar-Wai films (or La La Land, or any other romantic movies really) that I am left so underwhelmed in the romance part of the film. The parts that show the struggles of being an overseas Filipino worker are the best parts of the film simply because it hits hard when you know people that have parents being OFWs around the world where you can feel Joy's frustration of balancing between achieving her dreams and providing for her family. Ethan is a mixed bag for me where there are parts that are so endearing you can't help but smile at his line delivery and his love for Joy, and at the same time, I wish that Joy would ignore him or just call the police on him for calling her everyday. The ending felt really realistic as it closes and opens different questions of their relationship. People are mixed on the sequel for some reason, so all the more reason for me to check it out soon!

I appreciate this movie for showing a glimpse into the life of an OFW working as a domestic helper, and for highlighting the reality that many of them hold degrees that could qualify them for opportunities far beyond the jobs and salaries they’re stuck with. Kathryn nailed her role—her character felt real and easy to sympathize with. Alden, on the other hand, was weird and unlikeable. Ethan wanted Joy to stay because, for the first time since his breakup with Tanya, he felt like he had purpose again—something he found in helping Joy—and he didn’t want to let that go.

Joy, a hardworking domestic helper, and Ethan, a charming bartender, fall in love while working overseas in Hong Kong. It's a fairly grounded love story that reminds us that sometimes love means letting go. Kathryn Bernardo, as Joy, carried the film for me as she is forced to choose between love and following her dreams, capturing the quiet resilience of countless Filipinos abroad. We also get to see the emotional toll, economic pressures, and social sacrifices OFWs face living in constant hustle while enduring discrimination, homesickness, and uncertain legal standing. A reminder that behind many OFWs are stories of struggle, strength, and dreams deferred.

Overall yeah I liked it I think it's good there's definitely some stronger parts and some weaker parts but the story works and I find both Joy and Ethan likeable by the end and a sweet couple. Nothing against their romance because I think it gets better towards the end, but Joy's plot initially about working away from home and having to provide from her family and also putting herself first for once in her life is way interesting…

1. As my movie critic peg Json Javier said in his post " Who would have thought that the most unlikely pairing will make way for the best Filipino movie of 2019 as of yet? " Hindi lang ako nag aagree 100%. 100 gazillion times more.2. I intentionally didn't watch this as early as I should have because of Cinemalaya pero the few days I missed made me appreciate the wait. 5 out of 5 stars.3. Malamang marami naka relate na working professionals when Kathryn Bernardo's character Joy said that choices are just for the rich. Umoo ako e. Pati yung mag jowa sa tabi ko. Pati yung yuppies sa likod ko. Totoo naman diba? Kahit anong profession mo makakarelate ka talaga. Kahit mahirap, babangon ka at magtratrabaho. Pero may choice ka din naman na magbago o mag stay. Kung ano ba ang priority mo.4. Kudos sa scriptwriter for involving that famous scene of Anak. Kasi kailangan siya. Kasi epitome yun ng Hongkong stories of our OFWs.5. Think of all the superlative words you can to describe outstanding. Yun lahat ang masasabi sa acting chops nila Kathryn Bernardo at Alden Richards dito. Yung alam mong hindi naman sila aa totoong buhay pero akala mo they are an item in real life.6. Sasamahan ko na lagi ng ice tea kapag kakain ako ng noodles. Saka oo. Pasasaan ba't makakahanap din ako ng taong kasabay kong kumain ng mabilis dahil busy ako at marami pa kaming gagawin.7. This film will make you respect our OFWs more. Kung ano ang sinasakripisyo nila. Kung ano ang kaya nilang ibigay. Kung bakit kailangan nila yung gawin. Iba ibang istorya. Pero sumesentro lang lahat sa pag ibig.8. Iba din talaga tayong mga Pilipino pagdating sa pamilya. Yung ikakain mo na lang ibibigay mo pa sa kanila. Kasi iba ang saya kapag nakita mo silang masaya.9. Two people make a relationship work. Hindi lang isang tao. Kasi nakakapagod yun. Dalawa dapat.10. Hindi ako kuntento sa one film lang for KathDen. This pair deserves one more movie. Or maybe two. Star Cinema and Direk Cathy, we need a follow up please.

A heartfelt romantic-comedy-drama revolving around the lives of two filipino immigrants in Hong Kong. Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards were just too charming and lovable. The movie neatly blends their hardships, sacrifice, dreams, love & realities quite effectively with enough empathy. Though it portrays the struggles, it never demands your pity, but rather derives its strength through their stories and experiences, to ultimately empower their future paths. A warm satisfying drama indeed.

I felt bad for joy the whole movie, especially considering her family situation and how pressuring it probably feels since she is probably the only source of income of her family. Her family needs her. It’s understandable how she keeps rejecting Ethan. I would too if I was in that state, but no man is an island right? It would be better if Ethan and Joy stayed as friends. Spoilers ahead: It is not selfish of Joy to actually choose…

A heartfelt exploration of love, sacrifice, and personal growth set against the backdrop of Hong Kong’s bustling cityscape. The chemistry between Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards is undeniable, their performances grounding the emotional core of the film. The story of Joy, an OFW navigating her dreams and a complicated relationship, is both compelling and heartbreaking. It’s a reflection of the sacrifices many Filipinos make for a better future.However, while the romance is touching, the pacing feels a bit uneven at times, and some plot points seem predictable. The portrayal of the struggles of an OFW could have been explored deeper, as some aspects feel overly simplified for a broader audience.Nonetheless, the film leaves you with a powerful message: "That sometimes, you have to let go of love in order to truly find yourself and your own happiness." It’s a bittersweet journey of realizing that love is not always about holding on, but knowing when to let go and move forward. A solid effort with a lot of emotional resonance, even if it occasionally falls into predictable tropes.

watching this film again after almost 6 years made me think of the changes in opinions on how I see relationships

Joy, a live-in migrant-cum-domestic helper in Hong Kong, prepares to leave for Canada to pursue her dreams when she unexpectedly meets Ethan, and the two fall in love. However, their relationship comes at the risk of their personal goals and aspirations.While it's probably my third watch, this time with an objective, So here are thoughts: I felt some scenes were mixed with the usual pushy theatrics, overly focused shots, and an excessive number of romantic background songs unnecessarily shoved into the film, occasionally straying from authenticity and realism. Overall, the film manages to maintain authenticity for more than three-fourths of its runtime.Hello, Love, Goodbye offers something for everyone—heartbreaking romance, politically tinged drama, and uniquely scenic locations in Hong Kong, encapsulating both the classic three-night, four-day tourist spots and the lesser-known areas. It effectively captures the realism of Hong Kong’s live-in migrant workers, highlighting their struggles with abuse, poor working conditions, the fight for PR, Sunday gatherings of domestic workers, and the depiction of a city that never sleeps.Bernardo and Richards ignite the screen with natural chemistry, speaking volumes through lingering glances and long silences. Every shared moment crackles with quiet intensity, letting emotions simmer and adding profound depth to their connection, with moments of joyful humor in between. The film is lively and, at times, playfully silly, thanks to its ensemble of supporting characters, which helps create a feel-good vibe for the audience.I personally appreciated the character development approach taken by Cathy Garcia-Sampana; the first ten minutes serve as a synopsis of Joy’s character, unfolding family issues—from the rift between Joy’s mother and father to Ethan’s desire to keep his family together. All in all, the film’s emphasis on character building, assisted by sincere backstories and strong performances from the leads, enhances its authenticity. Additionally, the film’s setting—Hong Kong’s hazy skyline, busy crowd, and colorful, grid-like residential blocks—paints a compelling backdrop for a story that leaves audiences hoping for a sequel.

My Brutally Honest Review of Hello, Love, Goodbye (2019)Directed By: Cathy Garcia-Sampana Score: 76/100 Potato Verdict: An interesting character study of domestic helpers in Hong Kong, and addition to the OFW romance storiesPROS:1. Both Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards carried the film. Kadalasang problems for romance films is meron isa nasasapawan yung isa. Thankfully, they are both treated as seperate characters and people. Hindi yung nakadepende yung isa sa buong film. Iba talaga if non-loveteam film. 2. Alden Richards never disappoints. In fact, he’s perfectly casted as someone charming and funny but kayang makipagsabayan sa drama sa family. One of his finest performances yet kay no wonder he’s one of the best actors of his generation. Kaya I hope more quality films para mas mapakita yung acting. I’m a fan. 3. As a fan ni Kath, I can say that this film will go down as one of Kathryn Bernardo’s best and memorable performances. She’s better in roles na may maturity than the usual rom-com roles. Magaling si Kath magportray ng strong independent female character kasi mas ramdam mo siya and yung authenticity ng characters niya sa mata pa lang. I can really say na Kath is one of the greatest actresses ng generation niya. Sana lang bigyan siya ng mas challenging roles and better scripts. 4. Commendable for a mainstream film to portrayal of OFWs na nagiging TNT din. Naging strength ng film na di ginawang backdrop lang yung pagiging OFW for the sake of a love story. 3. Ang lakas ng chemistry ng #Kathden. Im not a fan of love stories pero nakakakilig sila and at the same time you want to root for them.4. It doesn’t have a forced happy ending because being an OFW means sacrifices. Buti wala na yung hahabulin sa airport then magiging pabebe then kiss with friends na kinikilig. 5. Balances romance and comedy. Pero hindi nakakalimutan na mature yung depiction sa OFWs. 6. Nagwork yung Star cinema cliche na magkaroon ng maraming friends like Kakai and other people kasi justified na meron sense of community yung mga kababayan nating OFW sa Hongkong. Natural for our OFWs to survive. 7. It showed the realities of underemployed OFWs like Maymay who graduated Education pero di makaapply ng job sa HK and ended up as a DH. 8. It also includes yung labor exploitation and taking advantage ng mga kababayan natin physically and emotionally. There’s a part where sinabi kay Joy na “I own half of you”. That’s heartbreaking pero yun yung reality na naririnig ng OFWs. 9. Ang cute ng character ni Mrs. Chung. She’s a natural. 10. Sobrang heartbreaking ng short encounter ni Jerome Ponce and Kathryn about their lives. Ang ganda ng execution and comparison ng lives nila. Dito lumabas yung acting ni Kath. 11. Hongkong as a brilliant metaphor of Alden and Kath’s love story. Unlike Barcelona: A Love Untold, mas justified yung location hindi kagaya ng ibang films na basta nasa ibang bansa. At the same time like Joy, stepping stone ang Hongkong for Canada. 12. Ang galing ni Joross Gamboa. Bentang benta sa akin yung mga lines niya lagi. 13. Maricel Laxa had a short but great portrayal. Great actress sana mas napansin siya ng iba kasi ang galing niya ramdam mo talaga yung struggle ng OFW sa kanya and being an OFW not because may choice pero because it is a need.14. Ang ganda ng cinematography and shots ng film. 15. Kahit nasa hongkong sila, maganda din yung may pa-Pageant knowing how Filipinos are so passionate sa pageantry. It also effectively shows yung comedic side ng characters natin. At least, may temporary escape and they can show sino sila despite yung laban nila sa life. CONS: 1. Very Predictable storyline and character problems. It doesn’t offer anything new sa plight ng OFWs. 2. Masyadong stereotypical yung lead characters. Just like any leading man, toxic and possesive si Ethan. I like how the actor portrayed the character even if overused na yung puro red flag ang male lead (The Hows of Us, Rewind, One More Chance, My Ex, and whys), pero ang creepy ng pagkakasulat kay Ethan sa simula. The stalking? Ang cringe di siya nakakakilig even if his character redeemed himself. Then si Kath she deserved more than umiyak and halos lahat na lang gusto niya maayos na problem. Di siya realistic. They deserved better characters. 3. This film begs the question sa dynamics of the new trend of OFW. Dati kasi yung Nora and Vilma OFWs, parents ang OFW. Now naman may Maymay and Kathryn how did it end up na children are now sacrificing their dreams and even love life. Although mentioned naman sa situation kay Maricel Laxa, but at least di ba sa generation nina Kath? 4. Masyadong forced yung ibang hugot and cheesy lines na malayo sa objective ng film to be realistic.5. Why do Filipino films really don’t invest sa soundtracks???? Umay ako sa Ikaw at Ako playing sa mga specific moments. Nagmumukhang music video. 6. I wish nagpakita sila na nurse si Kath na nagstruggle naghanap ng trabaho sa Hongkong when she arrived. Yung innocent version niya na akala niya basta graduate ng nursing. It would’ve been transformational to see her growth na that kind of promise is not true. That’s the fantasy na after we graduate may job ka na. Ang ganda sana may dialogues about Brain Drain ng nurses natin and grab foreign opportunities dahil sa mababang salary sa PH. Yung scene ni Maymay na nakarating sa Hongkong sana lay Kath yun. 7. Also Joy entering Canada doesn’t seem like a realistic solution we can all root for. Yes it has benefits but…… nasaan yung representation ng Pinay nurses who go to Canada who take exams and assessments. In real life, they still experience a much more complex and competitive process pa.8. There were illogical and avoidable moments in the film (running kahit sinabihan na stop, yung away sa bar) 9. May characters na halatang siksik lang and unnecessary na makasama sila. Maxine Medina and Jameson Blake.

they engaged ethan's (alden richards) character into a playboy-turned-humbled archetype - genuinely falling in love with joy (kathryn bernardo), despite the latter's constant disregard to his actions when initially pursuing her. the film provides a definite picture of the fate of their relationship, though cute and sweet, is quite less interesting, honestly. not to mention the soundtrack of the film (charot). and this is coming from the fact that they also chose to navigate a much essential story: the collective plight of Overseas Filipino Workers (OFW) in Hong Kong. there have been numerous films capturing the stories of overseas workers. this film specifies the struggles in the eyes of domestic helpers in HK. joy is among those who has made sacrifices in an attempt to experience an economic progress. they have to live in a system that limits them as well, yet, for joy, she continues to live beyond the limited lines and risks her life for arrest and deportation. at the center, we get to immerse in the crowds of workers: 'veteran' workers hyping-up 'fresh' workers saying they will get used to it, workers busily arranging packages to send back home, phone calls of longingness and heartbreak, and we even get a glimpse of the tragic situation of joy's mother.kathryn bernardo potrayed the character like her rent is due. ang daming nangyari sa buhay niya with all the struggles, responsibility, pressures, all that continue to burden her, and she carried it all. and nasa punto siguro ako ng buhay ko na naniniwalang parang display lang talaga kung titingnan si ethan (no hate). but then again, this is direk cathy, and this is a romance-drama film.

Here, I realized that love will not force you to choose because love should be the foundation of a relationship. Another thing is that we are capable of becoming more than we think we can. The story beautifully revolves around the life of an OFW, shedding light on aspects often unseen by many—the need for a safe space and a reason to save up. Sometimes, life becomes hard to understand, especially when we decide to choose ourselves, only to meet someone who might also choose us. Like an airplane, it departs with a destination, carrying lessons, and the film portrayed that beautifully.
Ethan's Joy is here... always. In Hongkong. In Canada. In Joy herself.

Really disappointed with this one. For me this is yet again one of the most highly overrated Filipino film mainly because it stars two very famous young talents of today.The plot was good but it was not amazing or special or different in any other way. There are times when the character's lines were too deep that it doesn't feel normal at all. Maybe they've adapted this deep and hurtful "hugot" lines because that's what catches viewer's attention when watching trailers and that's what is used for memes on social media. Alden Richards proved to people that he does know how to act. He has this charm that can make you swoon but it was not enough for me to feel a spark between him and Kathryn Bernardo.Kathryn just keeps getting better and better. Her acting on this film is way more mature than those of her other films. It's sad that her performance and Alden's was not on the same level. You can really feel that gap during the climax when they were throwing overly dramatic lines with each other.Cinematography is good especially during the first part and the climax. I love how the pallette switches from vivid & strong colors in the drama's "hardworking" scenes to dark, warm colors for its personal and intimate parts. Not that crazy about the scoring though. Filled with long dialogues,and clichés, Hello Love, Goodbye still did not capture the drama of being an OFW in Hongkong. It tried, and it did on the first half but ultimately it failed because that part was later merely used as a tool to make a different setting for a love story. Being a romantic movie, the film was not something worth remembering. Even though the hard to get scenes and perseverance to woo the woman are there, it remains on the box of a typical romance flick which we have already seen a number of times. It sure adapted a different ending from our most typical Pinoy movie hits back then but the execution of presenting the reason behind it was not that powerful as well.
This filipino movie though, Bernardo’s best performance yet. Should’ve won the Urian back in 2019.

I started December with a classic Filipino movie I hadn't watched. Recently, the sequel was released, so my boyfriend and I wanted to watch the first one first!.*Ethan is manipulative, yet his character feels very realistic. He loves Joy and would do anything to make her stay, forcing himself to make suggestions. But I admit it feels creepy.Joy's character, on the other hand, was beautifully written. The hardships of being an OFW were fully shown. I teared up when she said goodbye to Annie. The fact that she declined Ethan's offer was also valid and I applaud her for that.Overall, it would've been a 4 star if Ethan wasn't manipulative. I still enjoyed it and would totally recommend <3

Kakaiba ang kwentong ito sa mga nakasanayan nang romance drama na ang mensahe palagi ay "may forever". Napakapraktikal at conscious ng mga tauhan dito sa usapin ng pag-ibig at kabiguan dito. Pero sa kabilang banda, naging transaksyunal ang pag-iibigan na halos ekstensyon lamang ito ng isang hookup. Ang konseptong "sex lang ito" ay pinahaba lamang hanggang sa takdang panahon ng pinagsisikapang paglisan. Una ang sarili, ang sikmura, ang ekonomiya ng sariling pamilya, bago ang kaligayahan ng dalawang umiibig. Ang lungkot ng mundong walang kasiguruhan sa batayang pangangailangan, sa mundo na una ang pagpapalago ng kapital bago ang kaligayahan ng mamamayan.

Hello, Love, Goodbye comes across as the Philippines’ La La Land but grounded in its culture and story. A romance drama that shows the bitter reality of people trying to chase their dreams in tough situations. Actors Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards are sensational and display immaculate chemistry. The realistic story about love/dreams, will touch your heart and soul. As someone who is half Filipino, it was eye opening experience to witness the hardships of my culture. Hello, Love, Goodbye is a great romance drama filled with hard truths and reality. But with added beauty and pain to create a wonderful film. So I saw the sequel to this film Hello, Love, Again currently in theaters first. It was my introduction to Philippines cinema. Once I was informed on twitter that there’s a first film, I decided to check it out. The plot of Hello, Love, Goodbye is pretty clear cut. Set in Hong Kong, a Filipina domestic helper working hard to make the move to Canada meets a Filipino bartender trying to help his family. Even with the truth and circumstances laid out these two are drawn to each other. Leading to a honest portrayal of love, with all the highs and lows that come attached with it. It was refreshing to see a story feature characters who don’t have everything together and are also struggling. Made things feel more genuine and authentic to me. Especially prominent in the brief little joys, no pun intended and adventures they partake in to escape their reality This film did a good job of hitting you hard in the feels. Some might not like how it ended but I did. If you are a dreamer like myself, it made perfect sense. Only gripe is the humor, majority of it, isn’t my cup of tea. I really have to commend actor Kathryn Bernardo for giving us such a gripping performance as Joy. Her character goes through so much that she has to endure to maintain focus on her dream. Luckily Kathryn Bernardo really gave her best to convey the various emotions of Joy’s situation brilliantly. She had the best performance in the movie. Her co-star Alden Richards matched her incredible acting and energy with his character Ethan. Unlike Joy, I was conflicted a lot with his character and at times wasn’t a fan of his actions. But we can all relate to Ethan because love makes you do strange things. However Alden Richards adds a lot of charm and sincerity to Ethan. Hello, Love, Goodbye is an excellent romance drama from the Philippines. Even though it’s ingrained fully into its culture, it can be easily enjoyed by everyone. For we all have been in similar situations when it comes to relationships, dreams and love. I’ve always maintained that the best romance films aren’t the ones that give you the typical happy ending. This is what makes Hello, Love, Goodbye beautiful. As always, go watch this for yourself!

Joy makes the difficult decision to leave Hong Kong for Canada to pursue her dream of becoming a nurse, which puts her and Ethan in a long-distance relationship. As they each live in their respective cities, time and the COVID-19 pandemic take their toll on their relationship. After going their separate ways, fate has again brought them together under different circumstances and as evolved individuals.This is an excellent romantic movie with a good balance of comedy and drama. The story is simple, but the combination of immigration, a global pandemic, and a pinch of cultural humor makes it unique. The story shares how love grows and changes and how individuals must grow and change to survive and thrive. With a runtime of two hours and two minutes, some parts are unnecessary and slow the overall development of the story. This is a great movie to stream for a unique international romance.

I loved this movie. Not only was it a well-written romance film but it also added the harsh reality of the Filipino economy, focusing on how difficult the life of a domestic helper is. Joy and Ethan’s story was well-paced and it didn’t feel forced. They were really a nice match and I really felt the spark between them.Incorporating both of their family struggles with the economy and the dream of having a stable and comfortable life made the film more grounded and relatable. Overall, this film is a must-watch.

almost perfect honestly for a filipino movie and it went beyond my non-existent expectations just because I loved how it wasn't just a romance movie. found myself crying at the intimate family moments and struggles more. from a HK PR (sorry ethan and joy) standpoint, I cried at the simplicity of their big dreams in a small place and finding the beauty in exploring that. their first monthsary made me cry!!! how "small" yet special ): all the places and experiences are lived realities which makes it such a good watch because they made it a perfect balance of seriousness and silliness. their conversations in central pier, TST, and cheung chau hit different! personally i'm not super annoyed at ethan because i understand being caught up on your emotions, so i'm happy the ending was bittersweet and he didn't manipulate her (extremely) into staying. let's see if he's an asshole in the second film :p also bakit sila naglalandian sa harap ng Tin Hau Temple HAHAHA wag tularan

Ranking this higher on my second watch, a few years after the first. There truly are a few moments (and a few lines meant to be comedic) this could have done without, but overall, it is easy to understand how and why this became a classic.Sure, it's a love story, first and foremost. But it's also the story of OFWs, of people trying to make it in a country outside their own, as people fighting not only for survival but also trying to hold on to their dreams, to make them come true. I just love the well-roundedness of this movie. Insightful and humanizing, on top of it being entertaining.

timeless classic, a beloved filipino movie that made its mark on cinema history. Back in 2019, there was so much chaos in the Philippines, station wars, loveteams flopping, and everything in between. Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards had one shot to save it... and they freaking did!Two of the most influential Filipino celebrities teamed up and broke our hearts. Major kudos to them! Rewatching this movie now, especially with the sequel on air, I have to say it’s been the most heartfelt Pinoy film of the decade. It’s so real and authentic, showing how Filipinos have to live overseas just to earn enough for their families. Joy gave up her dreams for others, it’s so unfair but so true to life, but this guy Ethan had some problem with attachment issues lmao, it's such a perfect way to end it without them being together. Alden Richards, THE MAN YOU ARE! Can we talk about his acting? I’ve never seen him act like that before because GMA keeps giving him mid movies (not to be shady, but fr) . No wonder it became a blockbuster hit."Joy is Here!" This first movie is pure nostalgia. Cinematic, leveled-up, and with a soundtrack that was soundtracking. This just made me want to watch Hello, Love, Again even more now that Joy is happier in Canada.

if you love me, why cant you choose?if you love me, why are you making me choose?filipino romance movies always felt really corny to me as a filo american, especially with those low quality cheesy montages and lines. but i always had a soft spot for them, especially due to how skilled filipinos are when it comes to implementing the perfect amount of drama and sentiment into their entertainment.this movie was pretty solid to me when considering how i was never into these type of movies. ive watched a good amount of filo romance movies and like i said, i was never a big fan. which is why i was surprised when i found myself appreciating this movie for different aspects and executions.first of all, reminds me a lot of la la land (2016) except filipino OFW version. as much as it hurts, i like to treasure those bittersweet or “tragic” love stories because its realistic. i live for the realism; the hope and joy whilst feeling that agony and yearning, bc i think it really shows u how things really are for a lot of relationships and couples; the reality. how it was never just about love and trust, but understanding. understanding your significant other, and how even when you guys do, the ending isnt always going to be “happy”. i think its a common plot and ive def seen it before!! i just enjoyed this execution and i liked the mature take on it. this movie felt like an entire leap of maturity for both the characters (esp ethan) and shows the growth of their relationship and of them as people. i also loved their chemistry, alden richards and kathryn bernardo as the main couple. i was honestly surprised bc i grew up watching some of kaths films and thought she never had a romance one without that daniel padilla dude. and i am NOT mad that i was wrong bc i rlly liked alden and kathryn together. they delivered the emotional scenes incredibly and i js loved watching them. i also appreciate another bare minimum feature (that kinda ties into what i was just talking about) but multi dimension. like i said, ive seen the plot been done and its nothing groundbreaking or revolutionary. but this movie specifically also had me looking at both sides, both dimensions, and understanding both. i saw how there wasnt a bad guy nor a good guy, how both were multi dimensional and had their reasons. i just loved how it was very clear and how raw certain scenes were.im giving it only 3 n a half stars tho bc i js still found myself cringing like hell everytime alden richards character was being creepy af and IDK theres js this vibe ab filo movies i cant get over. #lovebeingpinoy tho

What do you get when you mix love, uncompromisable responsibilities, and uncontrollable circumstances? This movie.The title sums it up really well. Three words that encapsulate what every couple in relationships fears -- "right person, wrong time". It presented a realistic view on how love can move mountains, but not one's dreams and aspirations. Although many romantic films opt to go for happy endings, I'm glad this one didn't. Ethan and Joy's motivations were so grounded and solid that it would be disloyal to their characters if they went another way.I like how the film also subverts classic romantic movie tropes by beginning with the first kiss and uttering the "I don't love you"s. It all made sense in the end and it felt earned.Let's see what the sequel has in store.

Hello, Love, Goodbye pulls us into the bustling streets of Hong Kong, where we follow Joy, an OFW working as a domestic helper. Through her story, the film powerfully captures the resilience, sacrifice, and quiet heartbreak of Filipinos abroad. Kathryn Bernardo’s performance is raw and compelling, embodying Joy’s exhaustion, determination, and longing. She dreams of migrating to Canada to create a better life.Alden Richards brings surprising depth as Ethan, Joy’s love interest. His character’s introspective warmth and grounded approach complement Bernardo’s emotional intensity, offering moments of hope and connection amidst the harsh reality they face. While Ethan’s backstory could’ve been explored more, Richards’ growth as an actor shines, lending a layered dynamic to their relationship.The supporting cast enriches the film’s emotional impact, with Maymay Entrata, Kakai Bautista, Joross Gamboa, Jeffrey Tan, and Lovely Abella adding warmth, humor, and camaraderie. Cathy Garcia-Molina delivers her best work yet, handling complex themes with sensitivity. Rewatching it, the film’s painful message resonates even more: love alone, often, cannot make us whole. This is a moving, memorable story of love and sacrifice.

At first, I wasn’t sure if Kathryn and Alden would have good chemistry together, but I was wrong. It’s a typical Filipino romantic comedy drama film, with a great cast and some cheesy but unforgettable lines. They look really good together, even better than Kathryn's last on-screen partner. The story is pretty much relatable, especially if you’re an OFW, because Cathy wrote it really well. She really pushed Kathryn and Alden into a whole new level, too. The only part that didn’t feel right to me was Alden’s character, Ethan. It seemed strange and creepythat Joy would let Ethan stalk her around in the beginning of the film, and he does seem a bit creepy at first. I don’t think I’d react like Joy did. But, overall, it’s an entertaining movie to watch. I enjoyed it and can’t wait to see the sequel this weekend!
