I just watched this to prepare for seeing the sequel with my cousin and I was not expecting much when I started it but already from the beginning, it sets up the story beautifully. It captures life accurately as an OFW with Kathryn’s character Joy balancing the hustle and struggle of living there. When she meets Ethan, it’s charming but not overbearing. The build up of their relationship was so natural. I love the scene choices that were made for the montage type of scenes. Then when they do finally get together it feels like a big sigh of relief. Even when it comes to the time that Joy chooses to take the chance to move in Vancouver, their conversation was honest. No unnecessary yelling involved then coming to the conclusion of letting her go for her dreams while still loving each other. It’s a beautiful message to end on.I also loved all the supporting characters. They had a reason and backstory as to what their motives are. The cinematography and story pacing was so good too. Excited to see the sequel tomorrow!

Gave this movie a rewatch before its upcoming sequel Hello, Love, Again (2024). Same feels pa rin, grabe pa rin yung tama nung "I love you all pero tangina pa'no naman ako!" ni Kathryn which is nangyayari talaga, kadalasan sa mga breadwinner ng pamilya. Imagine, putting your family as your top priority is a must na kung saan choosing yourself feels like illegal, ang hirap, na kahit sa love ni-restrict ni Joy yung sarili niya, not until she met someone na tinulungan siyang buhatin lahat. Ethan made the things lighter for Joy and he taught her na wag pigilan yung puso niya na magmahal kahit sa sandaling panahon lang. Gano'n nga naman dapat, sabi nga ni Ethan "kapag nagmahal ka, all or nothing. Kasi if you hold back, ba't nagmahal ka pa?" at dahil do'n, naranasan ni Joy na piliin ang kung ano'ng gusto ng puso niya. But in terms of loving someone, hindi naman laging s'ya ang kailangan mong piliin.. "kung mahal mo 'ko, bakit mo 'ko pinapapili?" -Joy, "kung mahal mo 'ko, bakit hindi ako ang piliin mo?" -Ethan.. this lines reflects the fear of Ethan na baka maulit lang yung nakaraan niya and yung suportang kailangan naman ni Joy from her love ones, to take the different path she want, that leads to her dream. Hindi naman palaging nasusukat ang pagmamahal sa kung anong kaya mong isakripisyo, kasi kung sa sakripisyong 'yon, isa lang sa inyo ang mabubuo, para sa'n pa yung sakripisyong 'yon? Kaya tama lang ang naging desisyon ni Joy "oo mahal kita, pero mas mahal ko ang sarili ko ngayon" -Joy. Can't wait to see what will happen to them in Hello, Love, Again 2024. Pero no'ng nabasa ko yung synopsis ng sequel parang may na-feel akong kakaiba eh HAHAHAH kaya parang ready na rin ako

Saw this play on tv, so mom and I decided to watch. The premise and the storytelling is good. It’s only now I realised that Kathryn Bernardo is actually a good actress. Probably her breakout role and what makes her a more serious actress.Also, had I not known that there will be a sequel, I liked that they made it open-ended; that it’s not your typical Pinoy happy ending. It makes it more raw and close to reality.Some highlights that stuck with me:• “Ang choice, para lang sa may pera.”• “Ang selfish ba para piliin ko naman ang sarili ko ngayon?”• “Mag tatagpo din ang futures natin balang araw.” “Let’s make that happen.”

With the upcoming release of its sequel, Hello, Love, Again (2024), I figured I’d go ahead and give this film a rewatch in preparation for the new one. I remember not really expecting much from this film, and I was honestly quite surprised by it. It is a fairly solid film that’s well-directed by Cathy Garcia-Sampana. It feels a lot more mature than some romance drama Filipino films, especially in how it tackles some of its themes. It’s also carried by its two main leads, Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards, who have great chemistry with one another. That said, the story is rather formulaic, and the characters are a little generic. But as a whole, this film right here was still a pretty decent watch.

I usually prefer watching western movies rather than Filipino movies because I sometimes think that the plot of Filipino movies, specifically the latest ones, are too cliche. But this film definitely made me change my mind. It’s a great film. Kathryn is an amazing actress and Alden wasn’t so bad as well. This film really depicts the sad reality that several Filipinos must go through due to financial instability. The director of this film did an amazing job capturing the real-life struggles of our OFWs. Aside from that, Kathryn’s character Joy definitely breaks the typical female protagonist stereotypes in romance films where the girl gives up everything just to be with the love of her life. In this film, Joy taught us that sometimes it’s okay to be selfish for once. Especially when you’ve been nothing but selfless all your life. In life, we have to make decisions no matter how painful it gets. Some decisions are necessary in order for us to have a brighter future to look forward to. I admire her character because it shows how much of a strong-willed person she is. Despite Ethan’s attempt to make Joy stay, she knew that this wasn’t the life that she wanted and that she could do so much more. Leaving wasn’t easy for her but she knew that she had to in order to achieve her dreams. Overall, this film is so worth watching. You know the film is good when Kathryn Bernardo is starring in it :p

Without a doubt, the film beautifully captures the realities of OFWs, and Bernardo's performance doubles it. I won't question how they weaved her character. I love how Joy chooses her own joy at the end of the movie. It was something that was empowering for me.Just wish they had a different narrative for Richard's character than the typical archetype of a guy who got traumatized by his past relationship, resulting into his playboy maneuvers in life—only to be changed by the female lead. His backstory was such a missed opportunity to utilize as a guiding wisdom for Joy while she navigates the complexities of her situation. Nabaliw sa pag-ibig, na-disappoint ang pamilya, and is now working to redeem himself. They could have stopped there instead of injecting the part where Richard tried to stop Bernardo from pursuing Canada.It could have been a love story that is self-sufficient yet consistently supportive. But oh well. What do you expect. It's a Cathy Molina film wherein stalking someone is apparently nakakakilig.Overall, I still like the film. The cinematography and the acting were superb. Sayang lang talaga character narrative ni Ethan. He could have been that linear supportive and wise love interest.

My biggest gripe with the movie is that Joy's decision to move to Canada is unrelated to her familial dilemma. She was going to leave regardless, and the revelation of the truth to her did not make her decision to leave any harder.I think this movie wanted to be a lot of things. It wanted to be an OFW story, a love story, and a Filipino story. The ending was a story trying to find a grip most of the time.OFW stories have the same formula, one person jaded by reality, and another who yearns for something more. It works wonders if done well, and the authenticity of this one really makes for an engaging world. I left the movie knowing that I understood the Filipino subculture that occurs overseas compared to movies like "Milan" and "Barcelona". But it gets old, and it gets predictable.I would love to see a version of this movie where Joy doesn't have to leave because she's grown attached to the child and the grandmother. And working hard for them is making up for the love she missed out on. The emotional anchor of the movie just didn't work for me because I know there's no question that she'll leave. But it is an OFW story, and the family she serves will have to have some hostile moment to make us feel sympathetic to her cause. And it's getting old fast.Also, the unrelenting stalker-like behavior really does sour Alden's character. And I find it weird that the script is spear-headed by at least 2 women.Will give it props that it didn't take the safe-ending - where Ethan and Joy meet somewhere and they'll both have it all. Their decisions have consequences, and I like that they accepted it in the end.

A quintessential movie about a breadwinner's struggle on her quest to achieve her dreams while providing for her family back home. The contrast of Joy's mom's story to hers shows that she dares to be different and wouldn't want to suffer the same fate. Having Hong Kong as the setting of the story enhances the experience. This is also a good starter for people who wants to try Filipino movies.

Hello, Love, Goodbye notes ⁃ Hirap naman may constant text message before the alarm, na pa pavlov si ate Joy mo. Mas una pa hinahanap text ni Ethan sa umaga ⁃ So nice to see Ethan adjusting his pace sa pagkain para masabayan si Joy hahah ⁃ 1 hour in ‘nung naging friends na sila, sinabi ni Joy: “Hindi pa naman huli ang lahat, you CAN be more”. ANDDD OH BOY ETO NAAAA NEED NA MAG BUCKLE UP kasi I think this sets up the conflict. Joy sees the potential in Ethan, but enough ba yung drive, dedication, and will ni Ethan to materialize this potential? LET’S SEEEEHAHAHHAHAHAH very familiar dialogue @ 55:22 remaining timestampJ: So, kailan ulit kita makikitaE: Nami-miss mo na kagad ako? ⁃ Nooooo, gusto ni Ethan mag open ng bar para maipakita kay Joy na di na niya kailangan umalis papunta Canada. MALING MALI!!! Always do it for yourself, not for anyone else. Especially kung para sa pangarap!! Bandang huli, magkakasumbatan pa niyan tamo ⁃ PAKYU SA TATAY NI JOY - ang galing galing mo magsabi na “sabihin ng nanay mo sa mukha ko na di na niya ako mahal” to “kung ayaw ng nanay mo, wala na tayo magagawa” after the truth came out WOW naman. Tangina talaga ng mga tatay. THE AUDACITY *insert PARKOUR meme from the office* ⁃ Tanga Ethan, don’t make it about you please. May pinagdadaanan yung tao. ⁃ TANG INAAAAAAAAAAA MAS SELFISH KA ⁃ OMAYGHAD AYOKO NA TAPUSIN KASI MEDYO PARALLEL TO WHAT HAPPENED TO ME ⁃ I was right!!!! Sumbatan galore sa dulo ⁃ Ethan, ang tawag sayo ay INSECURE ⁃ Buti nagising sa katotohanan ⁃ Good save, ganda ending ⁃ In conclusion: I fear tragic romance will consume me more than my slow burn romance fascination

Star Cinema + Cathy Garcia Molina is always a good watch. You can always expext a well produced, well written film that will captivate you from the start up to the end. One of the things I appreciate the most in this movie is how the supporting characters, specifically their friend groups, brought life and entertainment to the movie. While watching, I can't help but think how challenging to produce a Filipino movie abroad. I always notice the crowd looking or recoginizing the actors in the background. It is also noticable how some scenes seems to be forced or unnatural just to advance the plot. It also ironic how a film shot abroad will make you feel that it is really a small world after all, the characters are always on the same places, casually bumping into each other too much. While budget costraints are completely understandable, there is definitely a room for improvement. Overall, this movie did not fall short on giving you a classic romantic Filipino movie experience, giving you the right amount of "kilig" while also touching into social and family issues.

I rewatched this recently pero nakalimutan ko lang i-logFilm wise and considering it overall, masasabi kong mahusay ang pagkakabuo ni Direk Cathy, dumudulas siya sa gitna ng 3.5 to a flat 4 stars out of 5 starsSiguro ang mali sa film na ito is more than the film itself but rather ang ating pag-iisip. Napaka-weirdong lalaki ni Ethan sa totoong buhay kung tutuusin. Siya yung lalaking mapilit na hindi kayang tumanggap ng hindi for an answer. Siya yung gaslighter mong boyfriend na lowkey pa-sad boy. Magaling mangmanipula at may paniniwalang siya ang may kakayahang gumawa ng tamang desisyon. Una ko 'tong pinanood grade 9 ako, katorse anyos kami no'n ng mga kaklase ko and majority ng peers namin at the time e kilig na kilig sa mga moments ni Joy at Ethan nung bago maging sila, kahit naman kami, lalo na yung scene nila ro'n sa backroomPero now, in the eyes of someone who has learned and unlearned substantial matters sa ating lipunan at lalo na patungkol sa gender at ang existing system of capitalism and patriarchy e sa totoo lang napaka-uncomfortable panoorin ang character ni ethanFrom the character pipeline on him I mentioned above, nag-progress siya to this man na gustong ikulong si Joy sa bisig niya dahil kaya niya namang "mag-provide" at mabigyan ng "magandang buhay" si JoyIf Joy wasn't persistent about leaving, she would have been robbed of her identity as a woman, and she would be following the path of a million filipinas, a victim to the hands of a man dahilan sa kakulangan mga kalidad na oportunidad na inilalaan ng ating lipunan sa mga babae. Nakakatuwa na hindi ito ginawang typical love story ni Direk Cathy with the motto na love concurs all type shitTotoo, may pagka-predictable ang flow ng plot pero it doesn't erase the beauty of it anyway. Kailangan natin ng ganitong mga palabas na inilalabas sa masa dahil nagiging impluwensya ang media sa tunay na buhay ng mga tao and vice versa. Kailangang mabura sa isipan ng mga babaeng pilipino ang pagiging martyr at mapagparaya sa mga relasyon. Hindi tayo simpleng alipin ng pag-ibig, at hindi porket nagmamahal tayo nang totoo e isasantabi na natin ang ating mga sarili. Hahaha nagamit ko rin 'to as a reference to one of our discussions sa major subject ko sa kolehiyo dahil maganda ang pagtatalakay nito sa buhay ng ating mga ofw na domestic helper, ang pagkakaisa ng mga pilipino, kung saan e nagagawa nating tahanan ang bawat sulok ng mundo, ahahahah marami pang iba nakalimutan ko na lang xd nasa lec notes ko 'yon hahaha palompalo ako kasi discussion namin and a good reference will hook the students to understand the topic discussed much easily tapos mas mapapalalim mo pa and their interest lingers and boogsh a successful teaching style!

my mum turned on the TV and i fully expected her to put on a stereotypical cheesy filipino romcom where the man and the women have absolutely no flaws whatsover, the gay best friend/2 sassy women pushing her to “step out of her comfort zone” ending with the woman giving up on her hopes and dreams to be with the guy.but i was so so wrong.i was pulled in from the beginning. the story of OFWs in countries like HK and SG has been told in documentaries before, but i always felt so disconnected (?) from it, i dont really know why, until now.this movie really resonated with me having grown up with a filipino immigrant mum and her community of OFW domestic helper friends in singapore. in spite of all the pressure they faced to provide for their families at home, the abuse they may have faced from their employers, they were always so cheerful and somehow had the money to buy me gifts every once in a while??? the love and the culture i experienced growing up have shaped me into the person i am today and i will always be grateful.one of my qualms about this movie is the guy (as all of lifes problems stem from /s) and how he couldnt seem to respect her boundaries and kept harassing her until she agreed to date him??? girl, youre better than him. thats whats stopping me from giving this movie a higher score tbh. another is definitely the cringe cliches that still plague this movie. slightly forgivable given the other things i highly praised about.but i loved the movie’s exploration of women and their responsibilites towards their family. there was once a time i believed that we had fully achieved gender equality only for that idea to be shattered as i grew up. all over the world, women are the ones who leave their families, giving up on their dreams to work in an ass job in hopes of a better life. many women work full time and are yet expected to hold down the fort at home. women are abused every day. paid less than their male counterparts. seen as less than. and my heart breaks for these women, including my mum, who gave up on her dream of being a nurse in canada to be in singapore as a retail worker because she met a guy whom she would marry and have me.mum, i know it is not my fault, but im sorry that you could not make it to canada. one day i'll take you there, i promise.

One thing going for it besides an amazing female lead is its portrayal of Overseas Filipino workers. Many films have done justice for the hardships of OFWs but this film offers a more unsatisfied and discontent perspective. As most OFW stories is heavily backed up by there "willpower" to provide for their family therefore giving a more touching and empowering feeling. The film went on another direction that provided a sense of realism and emptiness. It's mostly sad but it's mostly true. Film is a gem hidden under pretty big flaws (sound and just the dynamic of the leads [loved the chemistry though])

As part of our lunchtime movie binges, Hello, Love, Goodbye is a "that" romantic drama that explores the complexities of love, ambition, and sacrifice among Overseas Filipino Workers (OFWs) in Hong Kong. The film's realistic portrayal of the struggles and dreams of OFWs resonates deeply, while the chemistry between the lead actors, Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards, is undeniable. The heartfelt performances and emotional depth of the characters elevate the film beyond typical romance tropes, leaving a lasting impact on viewers.

Mahirap pala maging OFW, lalo na kung sa iyo lang nakasalalay lahat ng pang-gastos at pangkabuhayan ng pamilya mo. Kapag may nagbabamggit ng OFW, ang lagi kong naiisip ay mga businessmen na laging nasa abroad dahil naroon nakastation ang trabaho niya. Hindi ko naiisip na may iba ring OFW na gumagapang na para lang may maibigay na pera sa kanilang pamilya dito sa Pinas. Ganoon ang realidad ng karamihan pala, lalo na mga Pilipino na tuluyang naghahanap ng trabaho— kahit delikado, para lang maiangat sa kahirapan ang kanilang mga mahal sa buhay. Paano mo na mabibigyan yung sarili mo ng oras kung ang buong pagkatao mo ay inalay mo na para sa buhay ng iba? At sa pagkakataong magiging mas kampante ka na sa kalagayan mo, paano kung ang isa pang taong mahal mo ay pinipigilan ko upang masamahan mo siya sa kanyang paghihirap? Masaya akong pinili ni Joy ang sarili niya. She deserves it naman, pagkatapos niyang magsumikap, mapagod, at mapuyat hanggang sa malapit na siyang makulong... mas deserve niyang pasayahin muna ang sarili kaysa i-sakripisyo niya ulit ang kanyang oras para sa kasiyahan ng iba.

ang pagmamahal ba sa sakripisyo lang napapakita?hmmmmm... if i were to give my honest thoughts about this film, i'd say it was okay? but then again it's also really not. all of the dialogue stood on a very thin line between cheesy and charming (which i could first tolerate) but at some point, it kind of felt like that it was all that the movie did..? and to make things worse, alden's character was the one throwing these lines. aka the weird fuckboy with stalker tendencies . so yeah i wasn't really that fond of their love story but i really really REALLY loved kath's character here! she absolutely nailed this role and i felt like the movie would've benefitted more had it been all about her story instead of us constantly hearing of alden's character's pleads to make her stay (when clearly, she wanted more !!!) but hey, for what it's worth, i really enjoyed seeing joy's growth as a character :') pass ako kay alden but i will forever be g for you kathryn!

may mga panahon talaga sa buhay natin na mas gusto nating piliin ang sarili over anything sa buhay. mayroon namang panahon na mas minamahal natin ang isang tao kesa sa anumang bagay sa mundo at hinding-hindi natin makakayang bitawin sila.pero, kahit gaano natin kamahal ang taong 'yan, 'di natin mabibigyan sila ng sapat at buo na pagmamahal kung hindi natin inuuna ang sarili.mahal kita. pero mas mahal ko ang sarili ko.- is a line that took the veins in my heart and placed it in my thoughts upang mas maiintindihan ko ang konsepto ng tunay na pag-ibig.maybe after all, people really do come and go in this reality. hindi natin pwedeng ipilit ang mga sitwasyon na palaging nasa pabor natin. marami talaga tayong mami-meet na tao na tuturuan tayo kung paano magmahal — at mawawala rin sila sa oras na tapos na silang gumawa ng importanteng purpose sa buhay natin.lahat ng storyline ay may beginning, middle, at end. dapat nating matuto kung paano mag hello sa bawat oportunidad para baguhin ang ating kinabukasan. dapat nating matuto ang pagbibigay ng sapat na respeto at value sa sarili upang mabigyan natin ang isa't-isa ng genuine love. at higit sa lahat, dapat tayong matuto kung paano maglet-go; sa oras na pababayaan natin ang isang tao ngunit tayo'y humihiling ng matinong goodbye.kahit napapabayaan na natin sila, ang emosyon at damdamin na naibibigay nila sa atin ay mananatiling tatak sa puso natin — magpakailanman.

with the announcement of “hello, love, again”, it’s was time yet again for me to visit this romcom gold mine. and for this second viewing, i have seemed to appreciate it a half-star more. the operatic, dramatized monologues and back-and-forths between joy and ethan have grown in me. i felt their words better than last time, somehow, and though i understand that these types of writing were manufactured to emit such reactions from the audience, i cannot deny the goosebumps-y tingling sensation i felt during such dramatic scenes. the performances i still find amazing, the dramatic scenes punched hard, the romantic scenes were cheesy but sweet, and the funny side characters were wholesome-ly funny. i did say last time that this was problematic, which if looking at it at one side, it is, but i think it was necessary to further enhance the stakes and to give the characters more reason to go or not to go ahead with their decisions. this problematic element is not in any harmful way being glorified, thus its usage increases the dramatic structure of the story and gives justification to the dramatic choices, thus giving layer to the characters and their inner selves. i’ve also come to appreciate some tiny details. the montage-like cutting was very effective in building the world and the budding relationship. maricel laxa played her short appearances amazingly. the final exchange between the leads was greatly implied like their wedding vows. and surprisingly, i didn’t hate the endless “kung ‘di rin lang ikaw” in the background. reading the logline for the sequel, i really hope they don’t fumble it, they have something special here.

You know what? It’s actually pretty good for the most part. I still would’ve preferred a slightly different ending that still retains Joy getting to follow her dreams of moving to Canada, but color me surprised even with the positive reactions, I didn’t hate this. As much as I disliked Alden’s character (and his acting. I’m so sorry), it’s a great decision to actually have him learn rather than have men like him win in the story even if they are actually wrong. Still, I am quite mixed on several aspects of the film. Script-wise, for one, I am aware that this is a romance film but I ended up being more interested in the OFW subplot. I have merely seen the trailer of Sunday Beauty Queen but parts of this instantly reminded me of that film. To bring forward a topic such as that in a mainstream film is a nice change of pace; however, it is instantly forgotten about and left unexplored by the second half. Some may say that the film already needed more time dedicated to the romance plot but I wish it was a little more consequential to tie itself to its OFW subplot. The dialogue is a little too on-the-nose at times as well, which can make some scenes feel a little superficial. Please get rid of full English dialogue between our pure Filipino leads, please, unless absolutely necessary (in which case, it wasn't).In terms of cinematography, I found it to be on and off. There are some good shots with impressive lighting here and there, yet they are never consistent as there are also shots that are too overexposed and poorly lit for my liking. I am aware that the motifs in the score would always be based off of a mainstream song, but having heard Kung 'Di Rin Lang Ikaw even months before this film's initial release (high school tingz), I find it to be a little overplayed at some points. Oh, and louder music doesn't always mean more emotional impact!Still, I guess the film's biggest redeeming point is its direction. Yes, it's a mainstream romance film, but it offers different flavor through its more mature approach. Spotty dialogue aside, the more emotional scenes work well on their own and never feel forced, even if they are a little too on the nose. I did not feel the chemistry of Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards at first, but damn it, Kathryn can carry hard. She just knows how to ground her character so well without making it feel superficial. Some people are probably tired of the comedic 'sidekick' best friend(s) of the lead female character but I personally found Kakai Bautista to be hilarious. Not all of her jokes land, but when they do, it's absolutely funny (the Vilma Santos scene probably got the loudest laugh out of me). And holy fuck, I knew that was Jameson Blake playing Peter! Why is he just so good at everything, even in playing an annoying character?Everything said here may have come across as if the negatives outweight the positives but Hello, Love, Goodbye is thankfully saved by Garcia-Sampana's (no longer Garcia-Molina) honest direction and Bernardo's strong acting. Perhaps its approach to showing the OFW life in Hong Kong can be shallow, but it's a good first step to bringing that story tied with its main romance plot into a mainstream Filipino film. Other aspects are quite weak (God, I'm sorry, but I couldn't stand Alden's acting), and perhaps a slightly different ending would have sufficed, yet by the end of it, it didn't feel poorly-made for the sake of profit. By utilizing the appeal of the two leads from their own different loveteams to tell a new romance story, it gets its point across effectively. Once the credits have rolled, I was relieved that I did not hate it, even if it's not quite my thing.P.S. I haven’t heard Ikaw At Ako in so long (high school has officially been very long ago for me) and I had no idea it would play here, nor have I known that I would hear J@$0n M@rv!n’s voice again 2-3 years P.P.S. Fuck Ethan lol thank God Joy questioned her place in his plans bc even I was thinking about the fact that he only ever thought about himselfEDIT: NAWT THEM ANNOUNCING A SEQUEL AS SOON AS I POSTED THIS REVIEW LMAOOOOOO

Watched Hello, Love, Goodbye at SM North EDSA Cinema 6.Its first hour & last 15 minutes tells an interesting, heartening, compelling and high-spirited OFW story fueled with great acting from Kathryn Bernardo. But Director Cathy Garcia Molina defecates those usual Star Cinema formulaic SHIT that stinks the middle part of the storyTOO BAD!The first hour of Hello Love Goodbye sets up an interesting & heartening plot & main character.Kathryn Bernardo portrays an empowering existential libertarian take of a Pinay OFW torn between her JOY dreams & obligation.But Director Cathy Garcia Molina poops many formulaic Star Cinema SHIT ruining the film.Hello Love Goodbye reminds me of Kita KitaHello Love Goodbye could've followed the cinematic style and storytelling structure of Kita Kita to be a great film.Kathryn BernardoAlden Richards is comparable with Alessandra De Rossi  Empoy Marquez#Kathden ~= #AlempoyIf only Direk Sigrid Bernardo be the director instead of Cathy Garcia-MolinaHello Love Goodbye could've been a great, well-made and well-treated film.Hello Love Goodbye works only at its first hour and its last 15 minutes of the film.The film lays out an interesting and compelling plot as well as a Kathryn Bernardo main character as Joy that we would all sympathize and root for.The concept of spiritually living in transit in a strange foreign land working hard to make a desired reality happen one day is the film's conceit that really hits hard to all of us. In this modern, demanding and even depriving world we are living in, we are all racing against time to reach our desired goals in life or else we would never achieve it.No time for JOY, no time for LOVE, no time to enjoy our current disposition NOW.This is pretty SMART stuff for a Filipino OFW story.We always watch Filipino films about OFWs where the OFW main character always sacrifices his/her life and personal well-being to fulfill his/her responsibilities to the family he/she left behind in the Philippines.This is a long worn-out story and we had enough of it.Hello Love Goodbye turns the table around.Instead of highlighting the selfless sacrifice of a typical Filipino OFW, the film smartly tackles an examination of a lonely OFW's existence in a foreign land balancing what he/she really likes against what he/she is supposed to do.I believe Hello Love Goodbye opens this paradigm which really hooks my attention and root for the story.Kita Kita almost touches this ingenious examination of OFW but never gets there as Direk Sigrid Bernardo never intends to portray such theme. Direk Cathy Garcia-Molina since "My Perfect You", "The Hows of Us" and "Three Words To Forever" is exploring and digging further her creative mind in coming up with ingeniously joyous Filipino stories while keeping that worn-out and obsolete Star Cinema Filipino family rom-com formula.Hello, Love, Goodbye is Kathryn Bernardo at her BEST so far. Good thing she escapes and breaks off from the tight-bound clutches of her constant leading man, Daniel Padilla. Therefore, Kathryn Bernardo is truly FREE as an actress and as a woman. Without Daniel Padilla at her side, Kathryn Bernardo did not fall down but instead rose higher than what she used to be just as an eye-candy amateur teeny bop damsel of a brute teenage heartthrob debonair.Kathryn Bernardo as Joy in Hello Love Goodbye successfully and convincingly emulates the existential crisis a Filipino OFW has to face as she braves working in transit in a strange foreign land while examining her choices and personal well-being in life. There is a strong libertarian take on Hello Love Goodbye that makes me like the film at first. And Kathryn Bernardo's great acting make that happen loud and bright on the big SM Cinema big screen. Again, this is smart stuff and Kathryn Bernardo as Joy would be one of the most striking Filipino movie characters that I have watched. At least on the film's strong first hour.Alden Richards plays Ethan who is more of a sassy comic relief yet effective MPDG for Kathryn Bernardo as Joy. His character as Ethan started out as a male creep stalking Kathryn Bernardo as Joy in a misogynist distasteful manner that even Senator Risa Hontiveros would never approve of. I guess Direk Cathy Garcia Molina is trying to make a Daniel Padilla out of Alden Richards with Daniel Padilla always bullying or tormenting Kathryn Bernardo for her to love him. Ahem! Direk Cathy. May Safe Spaces Law na tayo thanks to Senator Risa Hontiveros. Any naive sexualized young male Filipino doing a Daniel Padilla or Alden Richards to a Kathryn Bernardo is a crime punishable by fines or at worst, jail time.But I really DO NOT MIND Alden Richards portraying as a sex-crazy playboy luring Kathryn Bernardo into a one-night stand. I believe his flawed character gives merit to the powerful first hour and what Hello Love Goodbye is supposed to be.But I do wonder if Direk Cathy Garcia Molina inject that sex maniac character flaw for the male MPDG to justify that one-night stand motel scene. Seems Direk Cathy and the Filipino masses are really after Kathryn Bernardo shoving her face to Alden Richard's bare muscular chest. OMG! No wonder Daniel Padilla never passionately supports Hello Love Goodbye!  I actually like the unusual pairing of the troubled & serious Kathryn Bernardo with the carefree & hypersexual Alden Richards.This unusual pairing reminds me of Alexandra de Rossi and Empoy Marquez of Kita Kita.The Kathden dynamic in Hello Love Goodbye could have been a more improved, more substantial version of Alempoy in Kita Kita.Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards interacting in Hello Love Goodbye is similar to those sassy Asian (Chinese, Japanese, Korean) teenage romcoms that I get to watch on HBO Red Channel. Only, the Kathden may be something more meaningful than a unusual campy romantic/sexual pairing.Yup! The first half of Hello Love Goodbye really sets us up for a promising story that I am eager to watch.Until the second half came which quickly abandons this great promising story for Direk Cathy Garcia Molina to POOP to us the standard Star Cinema formulaic SHIT that STINKS already!Hello Love Goodbye starts well.The film establishes an interesting, heartfelt OFW story, introduces a charismatic, relatable and empowering female Kathryn Bernardo lead character and builds up an uncanny yet endearing relationship between Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards.Am really expecting the real plot to unravel on the second half.However, I got appalled when Hello Love Goodbye suddenly shifts into your typical standard shitty Star Cinema family romcom formula that is so uncalled for!This really RUINED the movie!Depriving and ROBBING us of a great story to unravel.NABITIN na, NAGOYO pa tayo sa Hello Love Goodbye na ito!From an inspiring, heartfelt and empowering OFW story on the first hour;Hello, Love, Goodbye suddenly drops everything and shifts into a cheesy standard bloated Star Cinema romcom love story with lots of these shit:1. Unnecessary kilig moments, 2. Blatant over exposure of unnecessary supporting charactrers3. Instant falling-in-love that does not feel earned and 4. Speedy resolutions that does not make a big impact to the hearts and minds of the audience.So Cathy Garcia Molina still adopts her standard Star Cinema family romcom formula into the promising Hello Love Goodbye story even when the film does not really need it!Resulting to a big pile of mainstream Star Cinema SHIT taking over the 2nd half of the film.The Star Cinema formulaic SHIT forced upon on the 2nd part of Hello, Love, Goodbye feels like a typical shitty Star Cinema story of its own. Therefore, Hello, Love, Goodbye NEVER continues, NEVER finishes and CUTS SHORT its REAL and promising OFW story that it masterfully sets up at the start.We are DEPRIVED of watching a great story until the end in Hello, Love, Goodbye. The typical Star Cinema family romcom formula that Direk Cathy Garcia Molina is fond to insert is not bad always.This overused family formula does work well for some of the following Cathy Molina's films:1. "You Changed My Life" starring Sarah Geronimo and John Lloyd Cruz2. "My Perfect You" starring Gerald Anderson and Pia Wurtzbach and 3. "The Hows of Us" starring Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla......But NOT "Hello Love Goodbye"!Instead, this Star Cinema formula injected at the middle part of Hello, Love, Goodbye causes a sudden change of the story, making me feel that I am not watching the continuation of its promising first half.This Star Cinema romcom formula which thrills the Filipino masses, unfortunately causes a big void at the 2nd half of the real promising story of Hello Love Goodbye.Which is TOO BAD and VERY DISAPPOINTING!It is really STUPID for Star Cinema ever since to forcibly insert that singular usual repetitive worn-out family romcom formula on most Star Cinema movies of varying stories.FUCK! SO STUPID INDEED!While this worn-out formula works on some films, it FAILS miserably and RUINS so many Star Cinema films.Including "Hello, Love, Goodbye" as its latest casualty!The audience never gets to watch the REAL, more heartfelt OFW story of Kathryn Bernardo as Joy and her libertarian existential adventures with Alden Richards as Ethan.Instead, we get to watch another typical Star Cinema formulaic romantic SHIT which should not be part of the real story.Just like any other typical Star Cinema filmsHello Love Goodbye is so BLOATED.1. Maymay Entrata is so underutilized! Although she has a charming potential to have an Pinay HK OFW movie of her own.2. Alden Richards as Ethan's personal existential struggle may not be necessary but should not be emphasized as much as the struggles of Kathryn Bernardo as Joy.3. Alden Richards as Ethan's family should never be one of the main focus of the film.4. Alden and Kathryn's friends should never overstay their welcome to the real story.5. Maxine Medina is a beautiful yet useless distraction to the movie!6. Those kilig scenes are so forced upon Alden Richards and Kathryn Bernardo. The REAL story does not even require for Ethan and Joy to madly fall in love and become sassy sweethearts.7. Finally, the interesting sub-story of Maricel Laxa as Joy's mother who is forced to marry a foreigner to secure a resident's visa is so not explored further. Too bad!These bloated 2nd half of Hello Love Goodbye gives us unnecessary SHIT while DEPRIVING us of the real stakes of the story that really matter.I assume that Cathy Garcia Molina intend to portray the over-glamorized 2nd hour to be Ethan and Joy's existence in the NOW.With this, the film really falters.But Hello, Love, Goodbye redeemed itself on the last 15 minutes of the film.It is actually the real resolution to the existential OFW crisis that both Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards are facing.But it is TOO LATE!A big void is left on the 2nd half of the film which fails to bear fruit the promising OFW story that the film first introduces to us.Hello, Love, Goodbye could have worked if its 2nd hour is a more serious, more composed, yet truly heartfelt & intelligently memorable adventures solely between Kathryn Bernardo as Joy and Alden Richards as Ethan.Both would continue to explore their libertarian existence together either as lovers or bffs. As they continue to work their asses off in Hong Kong, they continue to examine their existence, wants, needs, priorities and obligations.And that is where their prospect about love in the world of constant demands and uncertainties take place.All other supporting characters interact at their minimum as the real Hello Love Goodbye story is soley focused on Alden and Kathryn.This is how the movie should be if it were serious enough to be a great movie.I guess Hello Love Goodbye could've worked if it follows the story and cinematic style of Kita Kita.I do wish Cathy Garcia Molina consulted with Sigrid Bernardo on how to make Hello, Love, Goodbye work.Hello, Love, Goodbye is really a missed opportunity for Star Cinema.Rather than making a great movie which is a worthy follow-up to the great Quezon's Game movie 9/10.Star Cinema chose to inject the usual mainstream formulaic SHIT that really leaves a void on the potentially inspiring OFW story which really shortchanges the audience outright!P.S. As Hello, Love, Goodbye is an exhibition of Kathryn Bernardo at her bestAlden Richards at first plays a convincing & effective uncanny free-spirited character worthy of a companion for Kathryn Bernardo.Too bad Direk Cathy Garcia Molina fails to handle Alden Richards's good talent well in the film as she foolishly swings his character from a free-spirited sex-crazed playboy into a more serious yet passionate romantic.With this, Alden Richards still performs his best in his previous film, "Imagine You and Me" as Direk Mike Tuveria really puts Alden's talent to good use to make the ALDUB film work somehow."The Hows Of Us" may not be a great film. But its strength is its middle part which Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla exhibits that magical romantic feeling artfully around an old house that is really glamorously teasing our emotions.Some scenes before that mid-scene and the later scenes after are somewhat unnecessary and could be SHIT.But it didn't damage the story for its mid-scene is awesome."Hello, Love, Goodbye" is the opposite.The first half and the last 15 minutes of the film are GOLD in the story.However, the middle second half of the film suddenly turns to SHIT which irreversibly DAMAGED the integrity of the entire story and film.Finally, I also complain on how Hello, Love, Goodbye visually depicts the beautiful Hong Kong.The unusually bright lighting on various Hong Kong settings are slightly irritating to the eyes.I can't really determine if Hello, Love, Goodbye has poor cinematography or Direk Cathy Molina intends to have this visual flaw on purpose to support the real theme & message of the film.

You can look past through the sappy by it being filled with palpable OFW stories and heartfelt moments of almost every character (that scene when Joy sees her Nursing classmate having his honeymoon in HK, then is asked what is she doing there, what a tearjerker).It has many subplots about family, self-worth, career, and brief encounters that can stand alone, but their sum is a surprising and refreshing experience.(so much better when rewatched)

It’s actually good! There were parts of the plot that would make a better, stand-alone film such as Joy and her mother, the tricks for survival for Filipino DHs in HK, among others. It was understandable that the movie fell for the blockbuster dilemma but in total, I can see how the writing process was thorough, impressive, and a tad frustrating.

It's the specificity that I enjoyed the most. There have been many movies about the OFW experience, but this one roots itself in the particulars of the Hong Kong domestic helper. They're women who have made the great sacrifice to be separated from their families for the sake of potential economic prosperity. But they labor under a system that seems intent on limiting them. They are given work, certainly, but they aren't free to seek other work. To do so is illegal. Joy is pursuing a dream, seeking a life beyond being the absent breadwinner for a family that doesn't feel her suffering. And because she wants more, she can't just stay within the very limited lines of her existence, risking arrest and deportation just to scrape together enough money to find a means to a better existence. In the margins, we see the internalized tragedy of a people convinced that this is somehow an acceptable situation: veteran domestic helpers constantly telling a neophyte that she'll get used to this life, a phone call back home that's about having to extend a contract another two years. And at the center, we learn about Joy's mother, whose tragic situation exemplifies the commodification of the Filipino woman, and the trauma that it brings.The relationship stuff is less specific. Ethan fits into the playboy made good archetype: a lothario who develops real feelings for a girl because she initially rejects him, and then seems to tirelessly pursue her despite her consistent pleas for him to stop. That's a lot less interesting, even though there are aspects to Ethan's story that are kind of intriguing as well. The film bends its story around the fate of their relationship, and it isn't quite able to make it feel weighty enough to stand up to the larger issues that the characters are facing. It's cute and stuff, but it feels like a distraction from the genuinely incisive examination of the Hong Kong OFW situation.But none of that erases all the good that the film does. Even as the romance takes the fore, the movie is smart enough to make it all feel burdened by the tragedies inherent to a people who have resigned themselves to the reality of a home that can no longer be their home. Also, Kathryn Bernardo is great in this. Joy is a fully formed character: an industrious young woman who has deferred her dreams under the pretense of a necessary selflessness, struggling under the weight of responsibility all while learning sad truths that will come to shatter her conception of the life she's been pursuing. There's a lot going on there, and Bernardo just takes it all in and makes it work. Good stuff.

This is a film I normally don’t go for. I chickened out of a midnight screening of Midsommar and caught this one instead. (I felt I wasn’t mentally ready for that haha.)But I was surprised because this one wasn’t a walk in the park too—it dropped some heavy emotional bombs. With grace though. I liked it as a whole. Was it cheesy/sometimes overly romantic? Hell yeah. But it was good. Because it was honest. Honest is beautiful. Well-acted, too. I cried lots. And they portrayed the OFW life honorably and respectfully, I think. Never underestimate an OFW’s plight. As an immigrant’s kid, I deeply appreciated how this film didn’t shy away from the messy parts of life away from one’s home country—the ugly parts of choosing to be displaced for some years in hopes of saving enough to build a better life for OTHERS who might not even deserve it. I liked the subtle commentaries. Life is unfair.It also didn’t present perfect characters, which is rare for a Filipino mainstream romance movie. This one had messy people. No hints of self-righteousness. And you can’t help but root for them because of that. I love films that do this. Remind you of the cheesiness and beauty of being human. Of falling in love, of owning pain, of being honest about hurting, of independence and codependency, of giving and dreaming.
ACTUALLY ENJOYED THIS. the side stories with their own families gave this good depth
3.75 Stars.

I fell in love with this film. It is a tear-jerker, heartfelt movie. Mga twice akong umiyak. Ewan ko ba bakit relate na relate ako kay Ethan. Baka pareho lang kami talaga ng personality, perspective about love. Yung willing ibigay ang lahat in the name of love. All or nothing sabi nga niya.Pero aside from that, yung hirap ng OFW talaga is yung central theme ng kwento. Yung pangarap mo versus pangarap mo para sa pamilya mo. Yung paano ka ba pipili sa ganun. Yung sitwasyon mo na wala ka naman choice.Salamat CGM for another worth na movie. Ang ganda niya in fairness.

Hello, Love, Goodbye starts with Joy (played by Kathryn Bernardo) saying something like, ¨In Hongkong we don´t waste time because every second counts and every second we are payed¨. The film works best when it follows this premise- when Joy acts as the ´kayod lang ng kayod´ breadwinner of the family and when she desperately searches for ways to support her dream of flying to Canada to seek a job and follow her passion. However, when Ethan (played by Alden Richards) comes into the picture, this premise suddenly shatters, bringing back the movie to its commercial origin.A DIFFERENT CATHY GARCIA-MOLINA FILMThis film is envisioned to be like one of the remarkable classic OFW films in the past like ´Dubai´, and ´Milan´. Fortunately, the film doesn´t settle for that vision alone. It raises the story, nuanced to experiences by domestic helpers based in Hong Kong, where it is illegal to take another job aside from being a DH. It also digs deeper, creating a more compelling and informative story about the overseas Filipino workers in Hong Kong. To this end, the film may be given credit for its thorough research.THE MIDDLE STUMBLESIt could have been great if the film lived up to that premise and made that nuanced Hong Kong experience as it`s core, but instead it uses the romantic narrative as a way to effectively communicate with its audience. It is here, in the halfway of the movie, where it fails to function as a compelling narrative piece. Just when Ethan comes into the picture, familiar Filipino movie production processes and cliches come into play. Take for example the Wattpad-ish treatment of Ethan´s character, the way he is perceived as a playboy and later on revealed that he´s not so bad after all because of previous traumas he had encountered, the cringey mix of English and Tagalog to try to create remarkable lines, inserting some product brands into the movie that never really contributes to the story, using some irrelevant sequences and drone shots that make the film look weird and the quality subpar, and most importantly the redundant score that´s being played using different instruments to create a grandiose melodrama just like every Cathy Garcia-Molina film. Truth be told, there´s really nothing that is compelling in the film´s second part. It all looks like a really long pantomime with ¨Kung ´Di Rin Lang Ikaw¨ as background.THE SLIGHT RESURRECTIONThankfully, all the second part craze undos itself in the film´s last few minutes. Here, the struggles of both Joy and Ethan are discussed and are powerfully put together to give the film a compelling touch, grounded to the themes presented in the film´s opening. The last few minutes of the film however still feels like a long music video. Only this time, it´s disguised as a travelogue. Although, it is in this long sequence where the most delightful shots are shown, it kind of feels just like a long compilation of tourist vlogs rather than an essential part of the story. Another resurrection comes at the film´s last minute. It brilliantly presents the resolution, bringing it to a powerful last shot reminiscent to that of Alfonso Cuaron´s `Roma´, but more explicitly told.THE BEST OF KATHRYNI never thought I would say this, but this is definitely Kathryn´s film. Though this is her most daring and demanding role yet, she perfectly portrays Joy´s desperation, desire, and inherent sadness. This performance is her all-time best and I can, with no doubt say that it is something that should seriously be considered by the country´s award-giving bodies. Alden Richard´s Ethan however feels like a character that was written for Kathryn´s on-screen partner, Daniel Padilla. Despite this, Alden Richards still plays the role with heart. Unlike Kathryn´s role, Ethan is not a dramatically demanding character. This is somehow opposite to Richards´ past roles which never fails to use tears and eye acting as tools for storytelling. In the end, it feels like Alden is only a supporting character in this movie. INCONSISTENTLY GOODSometimes, Hello, Love, Goodbye struggles to cope up with it´s promising premise. At one point it proudly flaunts it´s technical excellence, and the next thing you see, a drone is randomly used to show a scene where the main characters are running on a rooftop. Sometimes it also shines as a narrative piece while the next second, it reeks of shit. This film has a lot of potential, in all honesty. However, it does not consistently makes use of that potential, and most of the time it acts like one of those commercial films in the market- settles for the mediocre, and the audience appeal while sacrificing good storytelling. Despite this, it still should be regarded as a cinematic achievement as it presents a raw aspect of the difficult life abroad despite being a studio-made film.

Cathy Garcia-Molina has revitalized her storytelling voice. A good mix of crowd-pleasing moments and hard-to-swallow truths. The film didn’t pull any punches. It left me gushing and gut-wrenched at the same time.

Isang ehemplo ang "Hello, Love, Goodbye" na pedeng tibagin ang mga nakasanayan na nating tambalan, ipares sa iba pang tao, at pede pa ring makaramdam ng saya at kilig habang pinapanood sila. May kakaibang timpla ang tambalang Alden at Kathryn na hindi nakakasawang panuorin.  idagdag pa rito ang isang satisfying at hindi toxic na pagresolba sa issue nila sa pelikula.

Never have I ever watched a Filipino movie with the same typical couple until this came out, and this is one of the reasons why it was extraordinary. They had definitely given the audience another chemistry and vibe to maybe spice things up and break that notion of having the same couple on screen; however, what really made this movie so good is its plot. Every bit of its scene mirrors the reality of life and through that, true love is depicted in the story. You may bump into some cheesy and corny lines, but you could quite see how the two leads were able to emulate the vibes of Filipinos. If you're not into romantic type of movies, don't worry. You can still relate to it in some other perspective. Love can also be expressed in a platonic way. :) So, this is definitely a must watch.
As someone who’s so soft, idk how many times this movie made me cry!

Hello, Love, Goodbye is a film I didn't expect to like. I went to the cinema with a passive indifference to pass the time, yet I was utterly blown away once the opening montage scene started. It reminded me of the claustrophobic isolation and weariness of Chungking Express, which also took place in Hong Kong. I thought to myself that it wasn't a bad start at all and it piqued my interest, hoping it manages to be consistently good throughout. And it did.The portrayal of domestic helpers is realistic. It doesn't go all the way to make it a tragic story, to the point of being depressing, as it manages to be hopeful at times with frequent lighthearted moments. I have a soft spot for stories about OFW struggles. Being a child of an OFW, I've witnessed various injustices prevalent in the OFW community. The movie brings to light several of them, and they hit home.Surprisingly, I didn't find the romance corny at all. Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards both come from different well-established love teams, and I was initially skeptical that a chemistry between them wouldn't work. However, they manage to exceed expectations as they bring the best out of each other. Kathryn portrayed the role of Joy convincingly as a struggling domestic helper trying to make ends meet and realize her dreams. Alden portrayed the role of Ethan as your typical playboy, but he manages to bring out enough nuance to an honestly flawed character escaping the ghosts of his past.The cinematography is decent, providing enough satisfactory camera angles to capture the scenic Hong Kong backdrop. The script is pretty standard for a Cathy Garcia-Molina film but sufficiently witty, sappy, and genuine all at once. The score is average but serviceable. Certain scenes could've had more emotional impact and tension without the dramatic music. The acting of some minor characters needs improvement. Despite that, it's not distracting when you have two lead characters pouring their heart out in their respective roles.To conclude, Hello, Love, Goodbye isn't just a typical straightforward romance film for me. It had enough going on in its story to be engaging while being paced well enough. The chemistry is there, and I must admit that the movie touched me in a way that other of its contemporaries haven't. Ultimately what resonated with me most in this particular film is how it addresses love in the most honest and vulnerable way possible. Every subplot is instrumental and significant to the film's conclusion, making a brutal yet optimistic statement that I rarely see in romance stories in general.

My expectations for this were high because of the praise it has been getting, and it does not disappoint. Beyond the romance blossoming between the two leads, this shows the hardships and difficulties of life while living as an OFW (Oversees Filipino Worker) - the limited choices and the sacrifices the characters have to endure. Kathryn Bernardo gives a stellar performance as Joy - and this is possibly her best performance to date. She is clearly supported by her male co-star who reciprocates her performance though Bernardo is the center of the story. My primary issue with Filipino romance films is the direction the romance will take when the leads are faced with a dilemma. Usually it’s the woman who ends up self-sacrificing for love, or the issues of the man are not addressed while giving the couple their happy ending. Sometimes the ending could be a cop-out, instead of letting it naturally play out. This played out perfectly - it was sensible and realistic. There was no gimmick, and the direction their relationship headed addressed the situation the leads were in. This is one for the books.Also kudos to the cinematographer and the writer.

Kathryn's performance here was quintessential Kathryn, Kathryn on The Hows of Us was really the best I have seen from her. Akala ko I won't hold on to Alden's character. Parang nung una kasi it didn't match him; But to my surprise, his character grew. The way the film presented his character and how we got to know him better was very effective. (May I just note that Joross Gamboa's performance here was so hilarious? Like, as in sobrang benta ng jokes na kahit ano nalang din siguro lumabas sa bibig niya ay nakakatawa rito)Story wise, what I really did like was it didn't romanticize the hardships of our OFWs, it presented the harsh reality of working outside the country. Kathryn really captured it. The film wasn't really the dark, heavy drama-ish film but it made me reflect on the privileges that I have and shouldn't take for granted. Last note, sana mapalitan 'yung chroma part sa last scene choz

It is not a pabebe romcom film. It is not a puro hugot lines and heartbreaking songs film. This movie will prove that the tangent-line kind of relationship fate exists you might be meeting exactly once but you can still make great moments from it. So so so film.

A young Filipino woman working in Hong Kong meets a young bartender. She's about to complete her contract and go to greener pastures in Canada. Normally, I wouldn't go for this type of film. And it's by Cathy Garcia-Molina, so seeing her name normally makes me go to the opposite direction, having seen a few of her past films. But this one, to her credit, has a bit more substance. There's a compelling drama here about the plight of Overseas Filipino Workers (OFW's) but blended with the formulaic romantic-dramedy that is her bread and butter. They do the usual "hugot" emotional romantic scene in the end where they telegraph every emotion through overly written emotional speeches each trying to out-romance each other. But it's still a solid drama before that.

a breath of fresh air. it's funny and sweet and heartbreaking without trying so hard. i especially love the fact that it doesn't revolve around ethan and joy, but mostly around ofws & their life outside. kath is amazing ((AS ALWAYS !1)) and you can really feel her every emotion in each scene. i love how she knows where she's going and how she's gonna get it. also i loved the tour around hk!! the shots where ethan and joy weren't the focus and they were just in the corner, giving the spotlight to hk's sights. thank u team *dog eyes*
i will always believe I'm the love child of ethan and joy

If there's one thing the movie can really boast about, it's the strength of the acting between its two leads. Kathryn Bernardo acted her heart out in this. You can literally feel the sweat, desperation and exhaustion her character endures in her stint as a domestic helper in Hong Kong. At this point, she proved that she can carry a movie all by herself. Alden Richards also proved here that he came a long way from his pabebe Aldub days. His acting definitely improved and was pretty solid overall.Although I did have a problem with how the relationship started in the first half (Alden really was a straight up stalker, wasn't he?), the movie redeemed itself after, not just with how the relationship was ultimately executed, but the execution of the film's central message of how loving yourself over everything else is not necessarily a selfish thing. There's definite chemistry between the two of them, and given how successful the movie is critically and financially speaking, I'm looking forward to their next movie together.Another thing that I really like is that (without getting into spoilers) the movie could had easily ended in a traditional happy ending. They could had easily added a certain scene in the end to do that. But they chose not to, instead delving more into an ending that is whilst bittersweet, much more grounded and admirable. It made the movie had so much more of an impact at the end (and I already really dug the last ten minutes so that was something).Hopefully Star Cinema does keep up this surge of quality and care in its films. I mean, it's not a stunning innovation per se, but it's a noticeable improvement in quality (*coughs* Vice Ganda *coughs*). If there's one thing to be learned from this movie, it's that Filipino audiences do are starting to care on the quality of their local mainstream films, and less on cheap laughs and hollow kilig moments.

“sabi ko takbo lang, hindi harot!”it’s both nice and scary how this movie was so grounded in its portrayal of how class struggle seeps in and plays out into people’s lives. an all around great cast (LOVED the supporting). kathryn fucking KILLED it with one, and so did alden, if not without his cheesy one-liners but oh well you gotta deal with what you’re handed with.

Joy: Paano na kapag tinanggal ako, sinong kakayod para sa pamilya ko? Gusto ko nang pumunta ng Canada para sundan ang mga pangarap ko pero kulang pa rin 'yung pera ko. Si nanay, may sarili nang pamilya dito sa Hong Kong pero umaasa pa rin si tatay na babalik siya sa Pinas. Pagod na pagod na ako. Hindi ko naman ginusto 'to. Kahit isang beses lang, gusto kong unahin 'yung sarili ko. Ethan: Binigay sa'yo 'yan ni lord kasi alam niyang malalampasan mo 'yan... Parang ako, God Gave Me You. Me: ay shutah kah----Obviously non-verbatim pero grabe talaga 'yung gigil ko sa character ni Alden kasi ang laki na nga ng problema ni Kathryn pero puro hugot at pickup lines lang binabalik niya. Tuwing bumabanat siya, lumulutang 'yung kaluluwa ko kasi laging may collective "yieeeeeeee" sa sinehan. As always, tibagin na talaga ang mga love teams!! Ang galing ni Kathryn (at crush ko pa rin si Jameson Blake ng slight kahit pilit siya umarte).

I loved the film. Kathryn nailed it. If you want a rom-com that has a mature narrative and character driven plot. This is really a must-watch!

This film is what Never Not Love You aspired to be + a little bit of Sunday Beauty Queen mixed in.Such a good film! The characters are all fleshed out and their relationships were tackled and resolved masterfully. I'm hoping for a sequel.

this film will forever be associated with a severe headache.

Kathryn Bernardo was amazing here. She carried this film from start to end and I am excited for what's next on her career. Alden..on the other hand was just oof. I know he was playing this "fuccboi" type of guy but it just comes out as forced and cringe worthy sometimes. I love it when a romcom teaches our two leads about life and they do that here, the whole resolution to their problems were great. The problem was getting there. There were just so many scenes with Alden that I was squirming in my seat and TONS of over melodramatic scenes. It makes me sad because Joy's story here was strong and Ethan's but it gets too focused on the melodramatic scenes and Alden's "hugot lines" that it puts the film way down. I may look like I'm hating Alden but no..this was just a miscast. And those drone shots tho

Hello, Love, Goodbye (Review)CGM's farewell note to cinema is a sincere procedural on the measures of familial, eros and self love.Chungking Express and Before Sunrise, anyone?  I kid.This time, blockbuster director CGM challenged herself, or at least that's what I felt and saw. Apart from the word play and tongue in cheek banters we've all grown accustomed to most of her films, this one hits different. And looks different as welk. From the trailing shots, the hallucinogenic montages and moody shots Ala WKW, this really is quite the departure from the usual Cathy Garcia Molina. And I commend her for that, and obviously giving due props to her (presumably) auteur aspirations, WKW and Linklater, Hello, Love, Goodbye served us feel good familiarity and a bit of philosophy on the power of choice and chance.

Damang dama ko yung pagod ni Joy bilang ofw na walang sawa sa pag suporta sa pamilya niya.Di naman ako ofw pero nakakalungkot lang na delayed ang pangarap natin para sa pamilya, para sa mga mahal natin sa buhay. Sakripisyo talaga, selflessness at lakas ng loob ang puhunan. Tangina. Napaka importante rin talaga na piliin mo muna sarili mo dahil kung hindi, you will lose yourself along the way. Hay. Ang hirap.Kaya para sa mga taong inuna ang pamilya bago ang sarili, tangina, saludo!

The two main actors for this film are big stars and are part of the two most popular tandems in the Philippines (with different partners, though) so I thought this was going to be another teeny-bopper-lovey-dovey movie but I still gave it a go since this newly-formed loveteam intrigued me. I normally am not a big fan of romances but I was so pleasantly surprised by this movie. The marketing was mostly focusing on the love story (because Filipinos usually…

By far, the best Cathy Garcia-Molina movie in my opinion. Surprisingly, Kathryn and Alden definitely have a chemistry, even if they were in different TV stations. CGM really squeezed these two leads to their boundaries to deliver an outstanding movie that is well loved by the fans, the non-fans and the critics. It's not that over-the-top drama but the supporting actors really did all of that. It's a signature CGM move. The supportive, loud, hilarious friends can be quite an eye and ear sore. I know, it is to balance all the drama and stuff but does it really have to be OA (over-acting). The realism of the story is the selling point of this one aside from the lead actors. And it's perfectly portrayed and captured. You can feel the hardships, the pain, with or without experiencing it, it will hit you very hard.A sequel may or may not be needed. But I'm very satisfied on how it ended. Change is good. And we need more movies like this.

didnt have plans to watch this AT ALL but my grandma wanted to and i dont regret it at all. i luv kath always n forever, her acting is amazing as always. i think this is the first time i've seen anything starring alden and he's so charming and he played his part so well??? also the story was really nice and i love how ambitious kath's character was and how mature they handled their relationship. all in all it was great !!

I'll be the first to admit that I dismiss Kathryn as an actress simply because:(1) she is half of the Kathniel love team and I just find them so cliche and the typical Pinoy media play just doesn't do it for me anymore(2) I gave her (and Daniel) a chance went I watched The Hows of Us with friends last year and I spent the whole time cringing and regretting my decision to be there(3) I prefer JaDine because I feel they are more genuine and, basically, just more real (I don't dismiss the entire Filipino entertainment industry, fyi)Got dragged into this with friends. I had low expectations given my last movie experience with Kathryn, but I gave it a chance because Daniel wasn't in it and I thought maybe it would be a little better somehow. I like Alden, but I didn't really know how his acting chops were. I was pleasantly surprised by how the film turned out - the plot was honestly a bit predictable but it generally somehow felt more real and refreshing than other Filipino rom-coms (I appreciate this very much, given the number of stereotype Filipino films coming out in the last x years). Alden was great, and I look forward to his next projects. I'm sure he'll get more offers after this. His pairing with Kathryn, I'm sure, has done wonders for his career since this came out.I still think she has a lot of growth maturing to do in terms of her acting (my preference, at least), but seeing this film really changed my opinion of her (at least half of it, I suppose). Definitely still prefer JaDine, and definitely won't be voluntarily watching out for whatever she does next, but she has one less hater in me.

Refreshingly charming, Hello, Love, Goodbye offers a little something new. It is hard to come up with a good romantic drama for a new love-team but Cathy Garcia Molina didn't seem to have a problem creating a new tandem Philippine movie goers would root for. Set in Hong Kong, Domestic Helper Joy played by Kathryn Bernardo works her way to get a visa to leave Hong Kong for good by taking multiple jobs just to get by. She meets a charmingly cute bartender Ethan played by Alden Richards during the first night at her new job and the two manage to become friends and obviously boyfriend and girlfriend. Although it still had the usual formula, the chemistry Kathryn and Alden shared on screen was worth the watch and is a reason to give this movie a chance.

Grounded on the very palpable millennial tension of having to choose between love and ambition, between staying safe or going beyond what you’re used to. But the film is too self-aware, relying too much on its tension points to hold up a flimsy love story between two people whose reasons for loving each other, you don’t even get.

Wrongly marketed as a romantic comedy when it had so much to say about family, self-worth, and OFW/caregiver culture. The opening sequence was gorgeously shot and surprisingly heavy. It was also very refreshing to see Kathryn play a character so down to earth.

Hello, Love, Goodbye is a classic in the making - the perfect blend of the familiar Pinoy RomCom formula and its modern evolution. It provides an unfiltered and modern OFW story that transcends the glitz and glamour of being in a foreign country, tied together with a love story that could be all too familiar for millennials who are trying to find their place in the world. It’s the best work yet coming from both Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards, as well as from directing and writing duo Cathy Garcia-Molina and Carmi G. Raymundo.

saw this latest star cinema drama and i wish i could say i loved it. true, it’s a marked improvement from the typical rom-coms the studio is famous for but still, despite its spotlight on a subculture of filipino expatriates living as quasi-citizens/residents of hongkong, it is still saddled by the usual storytelling cliches and harrowing contrivances that makes the film less involving and feels a tad bit manufactured. the movie tells the story of ethan and joy who meets in hongkong at a wrong time in their lives — she is trying to get away from hongkong and live her dream in canada while he is trying to reestablish his roots and his relationship with his family in the island after a failed relationship in the US. it’s a good setup but it was not unfortunately sustained when the narrative decided to give more time on cutesy scenes featuring the usual go-to “best friends” that may be permanently engraved at every screenplay that’s greenlit by star cinema bosses. and i observed one very sad thing about the movie: i understand that the intention is good but this movie seems to be telling us that families, at least in the vision of the filmmakers, are the modern-day representation of “talangka filipino mentality” — in this movie, they seem to get, however unintended, in the way of the dreams, ambitions and happiness of the main protagonists even if the portrayal depicts the age-old child sacrificing all for family. ho-hum.disclosure: i saw the brilliant film “the farewell” one day before this film and i may have been unfairly influenced by it into expecting that all films could be just as good. this movie was a quick wake-up call that not all movies are good no matter how well-intentioned they are.

HELLO, LOVE, GOODBYE REVIEW Hello, Love, Goodbye is a film about a domestic helper in Hong Kong; her name is Joy (Kathryn Bernardo). In her last four months in Hong Kong, she met a guy named Ethan (Alden Richards) and at first, she is making him go away because she is finding money for the paper works to be submitted to the Canadian Embassy and not a friend or a relationship. But Ethan persevered and Joy falls in love with him. In this film, we can see the conflict in choosing between love or dream, their own conflicts as a character and the hard work and sacrifice of an OFW (Overseas Filipino Worker). First of all, why are there many films coming out in the Philippines about adult rom com? I don’t know why but all of them is a box office hit! It is well and good that they showed the harsh reality of the life of an OFW; as a family of an OFW, it is sad for us. They are doing the best that they can, but they are still mistreated by their landlords. As big as forgetting to fetch their children at school to as little as forgetting to take the trash out. There are a lot of stories happening at once, but they resolved everything at the end. These stories are a gateway to show the main characters’ internal conflict not just between them. COMEDY IS ON POINT! Just as expected with Joross Gamboa. Not too many and not too few, just the right amount of spice. Also, there are too many cliché moments, but it worked out well without me cringing. This is one of the Filipino’s illness when it comes to films; they are too afraid of just letting the visual tell the story. Lines are too much; they somewhat gave away the story before the climax. They did not let the audience think instead they laid it all out for us. I hope that they overcome this fear and let the visual tell the story. I’m also glad that they used the original artist’s songs and not just cover it. It sets the mood rather than someone covering it. Lastly, cinematography is meh, okay but I can forgive this one because they shot this entirely in Hong Kong with some parts here in the Philippines. Overall, I give this film a 7/10. Film can be improved by deducting some parts, cut down their lines in half and let the visuals tell the story. Although, acting is on point, I think Star Cinema can squeeze more out of Alden Richards. Cinematography can also be improved by using tripods, stabilizers and a professional drone operator (some aerial shots are jittery). This is your typical “love, dream and family” story but they added the hardships of being an OFW.

I specifically love the beginning of the film. It didn't feel like you'll be watching a romantic movie. Instead, it shows Joy's life as a DH and her story is just one of the many untold tales of the Filipino workers in foreign countries. Of course Kathryn Bernardo is a phenomenal actress and she immediately caught the audience's sympathy. A loving daughter and reliable older sister. Ethan, on the other hand, is on the other end of the line. A cute bartender with flings and hook-ups on hand. What happens when he met Joy? His life drastically changed. Although it does have some sappy 'romantic' scenes and lines that I felt like sinking to my seat due to undeniable discomfort, this is indeed a romantic movie for everyone and cliches are not cliches if they never work. Anyway, the movie is good. Both actors have great chemistry but then again, I think Kathryn Bernardo could fit well with anyone. Alden Richards has never been more handsome in my eyes. Of course, the funny bestfriends for mere comic relief. Kakai Bautista is hilarious to no surprise. Minus 0.5 star para sa pintong padabog na isinara pero walang tunog.

I love the sincere portrayal of the specific OFW experience of domestic helpers in Hong Kong. The romance wasn't new ground, but still relatively mature within Filipino sensibilities. But the nail in the coffin for this film: the tears wouldn't stop flowing as I thought about my Tita in France who lives her life pretty closely to Joy's.EDIT: Bumping up the rating because I started crying again.

Taena, iyak ako ng iyak kanina habang kinikilig sa sinehan. (Siguro dahil narin kasama boyfriend)Gusto ko talaga to bigyan ng four stars kasi sobrang refreshing, lagi nlng kasi formulaic local mainstream love stories. Kaso sobrang feel ko na restricted ni Kathryn at Alden sa isa’t-isa lalo pa nagcamera tricks lang sa kiss (!?!?) Sobrang ganda na sana, sana nag-all-out na. Minsan tuloy nakulangan ako sa sparks nung dalawa, kulang sa connection. Pero hindi naman talaga yung love story part yung nagdala sa movie e, kundi yung mga simpleng patawa, struggles sa pamilya, iyak nung tatay nang makita bunso niya (lalo ako naiyak sa parte na yan), atbp.First time ko pala mapanood si Alden sa kung anupaman and nagtaka ko mas magaling pa siya dito kay Kathryn. Para kasing minsan pilit acting niya, di katulad ni Alden, natural lang. Andun na din yung flaws, tulad ng may mga scenes na alam mong may mas magandang scenario para dun sa gusto nilang mesaage na ipahatid. Also yung mga unrealistic na linyahan. Sana mas ginalingan yung script imbes na cheesy at hindi tagos sa puso. Pero favorite part ko, of course, yung ending, sobrang uncertain ng life. Di tayo sigurado kung magiging successful si Alden sa business niya, makakabalik pa ba si Kathryn at magkakatuluyan pa ba sila. Ultimately, the future is uncertain and we can only do our best.

A surprisingly good but honest Filipino movie about the women who move to Hong Kong to find contract work in the hopes of getting permanent residency, but are unable to fully realize their dreams before then. It's a story about hope, sacrifice, and ultimately finding that little ray of sunshine that can make it all bearable. This is a pretty heavy handed movie that can teach a lot, but also comes with a lot of positivity.
The title says it all.

I didn't expect to like the movie this much, yet here we are— it deserves all the praise it's been getting. Some dialogues felt a bit cliché and that acting direction in one scene felt too calculated but the two leads were still great, nonetheless. Kath and Alden played their characters with endearing wit and charm, as their oddities make their interactions raw and believable. What I really like about HLG is that as it goes along it feels riveting on a simplistic scale, it becomes expressive of our own feelings. The theme is on the idea of love (almost didn’t work for me), but the direction pulls in the audience through its characters— I am every bit of Ethan and Joy. I work overseas but I have so much to be thankful for that I am not a breadwinner, no responsibilities aside from myself and I have a job that I wanted for myself. Movies are indeed powerful. This made me more appreciative of the life I have now— it’s good and a privilege, therefore I should not take it for granted. 6/10

It is a feeling of mixed emotions watching the movie. Once again, we are reminded of the diaspora of Filipinos or OFW's to well off countries such as Hongkong and Canada to look for better paying jobs, no matter what these jobs are . It is sad because of the extreme difficulties encountered by the OFW's. At the same time, I feel thankful that there are jobs and income to support the families back home.Joy's work in Hongkong is hard - her pay is reduced, she gets a part-time job and runs from the Hongkong police because of it. In the middle of this, she sends home money to the Philippines and finds a friend, Ethan. Happiness finds its own source and with Joy, it is in the Central Park where all the "kababayans" provide comfort to one another in the middle of a foreign country with an alienating culture. It is also in Ethan whom she fell in love with.The movie is well directed and masterfully portrays the lives of domestic helpers. Salute to Cathy Garcia-Molina! The script is tight and romantic which clicks with the Filipino audience: "when you talk to strangers, there is no judgement" and " I love you" (witty remark to mean stay away).Finally, Kathryn Bernardo acts very well, she is the next Bea Alonzo. As for Alden Richards, with his handsome face, he can go places in the film industry.
