5.5/10For me, it’s a very typical Pinoy romance you’d expect from Star Cinema, so I won’t really go into the quality and narrative of the film. What always fascinated me was how this stands as the highest grossing film of all time in the Philippines. Having an OFW-centred story would definitely play a huge role in this benchmark, since the OFW struggle is a very real experience among working class Filipinos. There’s a whole history behind OFW films that I’d love to look into further while I’m still studying Honours.It was also jarring to have watched this after seeing two Wong Kar Wai films these past few days — I say this because this film is set in Hong Kong. So for me, it felt like an interesting exercise in comparing both localised and transcultural portrayals of a country. I don’t really have a right to comment on the way Cathy portrays Hong Kong people, or whether or not this captures an “authentic” Hong Kong experience outside the OFW life, but this is also something I’d like to scrutinise more closely.I think I can get behind why people would see this as above average, and despite it being an average experience for me, I appreciate the film for what it is. I would love to write further about the film’s OFW narrative and transcultural elements, as they are both integral to shaping Philippine cinema as a globalised medium.(PS: watching Kathryn Bernardo sing badly has been the most cathartic thing I’ve seen all year)

Cathy Garcia-Molina departs from rom-coms in a touching tale of sacrifice and love in a city far from home.Leave to pursue your dreams, or stay for the love of your life? This is the question that Hello, Love, Goodbye asks us. This latest offering from Cathy Garcia-Molina, best known for her Filipino romantic comedies, is set in Hong Kong. Molina sheds light on the experiences of Filipinos working overseas by following the story of Joy and Ethan, two Overseas Filipino Workers (OFWs). We see their lives unfold through the eyes of Joy, a hardworking domestic helper who’s trying to save money to move to Canada as a nurse, and Ethan, a bartender trying to find his motivation in life.Hello, Love, Goodbye stars two of the Philippines’ biggest names from the two of the biggest “loveteams”—Kathryn Bernardo (from KathNiel) and Alden Richards (from AlDub). What’s also surprising is that Bernado and Richards are from rival television networks; in the Philippines, it’s common for actors to be signed to one network exclusively. Their performance in Hello, Love, Goodbye proves that once in a while, it doesn’t hurt to break out of your loveteam to grow as an artist. An Empathetic, Authentic PerformanceIn Hello Love, Goodbye, Bernado graduates from her teen roles and blossoms into a dramatic actress—a total transformation from her child acting days—in a tour de force performance. Richards rises to the challenge and exhibits his versatility as an actor, proving why he’s one of the country’s matinee idols.To get into their roles, Bernardo was separated from the cast to better empathize with Joy’s feelings of isolation; after just a week of filming in Hong Kong, she wanted to go back to the Philippines. Richards, on the other hand, lost almost 25 kg to play Ethan. Molina is notorious for her strictness with the artists that she works with—but it’s paid off as they are all household names, and her films have been blockbuster hits.Hello, Love, Goodbye’s love story is not new, yet it provides us with a unique perspective of the realities of being an overseas worker. The film tears away the layers of the OFW experience with sheer intensity. Shifting away from showing the employee-employer relationship found in other films about OFWs, Molina brings her focus to the OFWs themselves, and their families back home.The film strips down the glamor of Hong Kong, as we follow Joy waking up at 5am every day, hustling through the crowded streets of Hong Kong—away from her family, never catching a dream. She sits down on top of cardboard boxes on Sundays in Central and juggles taking care of her employer’s daughter and grandmother while selling power banks as a side job (which is actually illegal). Molina blends drama and clarity in portraying these hardships, and most importantly, tells the “whys.”The Burden of Responsibility“If you stop, you’ll starve”—that’s the reason why.Joy, and thousands of other OFWs, endure these hardships to provide for their family back home—a message that the film strongly reinforces. We watch as Joy’s friend reminds her cousin to be smart with her money so she can have enough to send back to the Philippines, as the same friend tells her father that she’ll stay two more years because they need the money.Domestic helpers only earn as little as HK$4,520 (US$576) per month, while working long hours. In Joy’s words, if you stop working, your family will starve. Making sacrifices is almost always a given—a harsh reality if you’re an OFW because you have a responsibility to your family back home. This responsibility that Joy carries is one that resonates with many other OFWs.But OFWs carry out this responsibility at what expense?Similar to Still Human, which also featured a Filipino domestic helper, Joy has a degree in nursing. In fact, nursing is a common degree among Filipinos with the hope of working overseas for better pay than what they can get back home. As it turns out, nursing is actually the dream that Joy wants to pursue, and being a domestic helper is just a stepping stone to that goal.Then Ethan comes into the picture. While a movie following the plight of domestic helpers and OFWs doesn’t really need a romance story, the love story still has a purpose. Ethan’s character contrasts with Joy’s. While Joy is hardworking, determined, and knows what she wants in life, Ethan is a happy-go-lucky guy who jumps from one relationship to the next and doesn’t know what he wants in life. But his character’s free-wheeling life also echoes Joy’s self-questioning of whether choosing ourselves over our family makes us a disappointment, or selfish.Joy laments the lack of choice she has in life. As the family’s breadwinner, her family doesn’t know what she has to endure on a daily basis. A nursing graduate that cleans the toilet and eats leftover food—“I’m more than this job, I’m more, and I want to be more,” Joy says.Surely, this sentiment reflects the many dreams of other overseas Filipino workers. They have dreams but they also have responsibilities that hold them back. Joy and Ethan’s romance show the heavy burdens and choices OFWs face on a daily basis. Even something as minor as buying a snack or not is difficult, because every dollar spent is a dollar you could have saved to give back to your family.Dreams vs. LoveA common Filipino phrase, “libre lang mangarap,” tells us “it’s free to dream”. But Joy and Ethan realize, as they try to make their love work, that dreams aren’t free. When you make a choice, you give up something.Joy and Ethan’s mutual romance story mirrors the same sentiments that their individual stories have: choices, responsibilities, and dreams. Perhaps that’s the reason why the romance element works against the backdrop of an OFW story. In this sense, Hello, Love, Goodbye isn’t just a love story, nor is it just an OFW story—it’s a story about finding yourself, and loving yourself in the process. This universal message is something that will strike a chord with audiences.Hello, Love, Goodbye‘s message is simple: give yourself the chance to do what you want, get back up from disappointments, be courageous enough to love and choose whether you want to leave or stay. The film doesn’t portray Bernardo and Alden as people to pity—it portrays them as human beings, with stories and experiences that empower them to ultimately choose how to pave their own way for their futures—with or without each other.

I found it a bit cluttered and tedious in the first half but it gets better, more focused and complex after the male protagonist’s family situation is revealed. Even then, I felt most of the time we were being kept at arms’ length from the characters; close, intimate shots were so rarely used. I like its very mature approach to relationships, though, and by echoing the ending of the sparer, more eloquent Endo, it illuminated the ending of that movie for me, showing that by not pursuing his love before she’s ready, the guy is showing commitment and hope, a willingness to wait. It showed his character had grown, also it’s something anyone who wants to get somewhere in life needs these days, so it’s good that Filipino films are promoting this value!

Finally, I watched the highest grossing Filipino movie of all time as well! Hello, Love, Goodbye was on my list since it’s official release. With the new pairing I took some time to get into the mood. All my Filipino friends confirmed to me that the portrayal OFWs is indeed a very accurate one. It was indeed frustrating to watch the everyday struggle and hard work of educated young people in minor jobs to support their family. Nowadays it belongs to the normality to support their families through migration. It’s indeed a very depressing atmosphere and all the problems and concerns were well portrayed by Katheryn Bernardo in this movie. She did an amazing job as usual. But this time the melodramatic vibe really flashed me. Same for Alden Richards. I have to admit that I had my doubts to see Katheryn in a movie without Daniel but all my concerns were for nothing. The whole superstar casting and the successful capture of the OFWs situation makes this movie captivating. I really enjoyed the realistic view and the reality that hits the viewer in every scene. The survival and emotional struggle is detailed pictured and I really loved it that the characters stay true to themselves, no matter how hard is life.To be honest, the depressing reality clash were indeed very much needed and an eye opener for a foreign audience. The movie promises nothing and stays true to itself like it’s main protagonists.

As a whole, the movie made me feel a rollercoaster of emotions. It was realistic and heartfelt.

Not related to the film, don’t bother reading.Kung may Letterboxd ang nanay ko, ang daming beses na niya nai-log ‘to. Every time I open Netflix in our TV it’s always in her “continue watching” lmao I wonder how many times she has rewatched this on her own. And she has seen it in the cinema with me too. Twice.  I don’t know if it’s because I have siblings working abroad that’s why she loves this or she’s just a fan of Alden lol. So ayun na nga, napa-rewatch tuloy ako dahil nakita ko na naman siyang nanonood (I think pang-apat ko na rin na nood ‘to ‘di ko lang nila-log).Like what most people have mentioned, Ethan is the definition of creep and sadboi LOL the worst combination. Also that December Avenue song instantly triggers my fight or flight. Maybe if this movie just focused on Joy and without Ethan’s annoying antics lol… but Kathryn and Alden’s acting are really good and I’m actually hoping for a reunion project. Really digging their on-screen chemistry.Just some interesting observations hehe. I love how Philippine mainstream cinema (like the highest grossing films) is dominated by WOMEN and LGBT+ (AS IT SHOULD!), unlike Hollywood which mostly caters to film bros LOL. *But also the irony that we have the most misogynistic, sexist, homophobic piece of shit as Pres * The way many people here support movies that film bros might deem too feminine, I love that for us. Like if you go out on the streets and ask an ordinary Pinoy any director they know, high chance that you’ll hear Cathy Garcia-Molina, Joyce Bernal, Antoinette Jadaone, which is the exact opposite in the international scene where names like Lav Diaz (deserved tho), Brillante Mendoza, or Erik Matti are more recognized (well Isabel Sandoval too but just referring to the ones based in PH).Well, at least female directors are popular amongst the locals haha (unlike in other countries where the local and international scene are still heavily dominated by male directors). Anyways, overall I still enjoyed this but istg we really need tighter storylines and perhaps bigger budget for these mainstream movies lmao.

Sorry talaga, direk Cathy kasi I first watched this on my laptop thru a Google Drive link. Now I saw this on TV. Ganda pa rin. Kathryn Bernardo has really improved, her performance here aged well. You can feel her heartache, longing, and regret through her eyes and body language. She really did well in portraying the struggle of our Filipina DHs.Hong Kong, so close yet so far. It's a colonial outpost that serves as a microcosm of global labor relations: tired, underpaid, overworked, yet cheerful, patient Third World women on its busy shopping streets facing their haughty, cruel, and privileged Cantonese bosses who pride themselves in their neocolonial, Anglo-Saxon upbringing. The story is really familiar to me. I saw how many women in my family worked abroad (and some in HK) and faced such hardships to provide for their own families here. I hate how Filipinos are conditioned and trained to be machines for labor export. I hope the Philippine Revolution finally succeeds soon.

Film # 833 of the 13% challengeDirector Cathy Garcia-MolinaWhat a nice surprise to find out the highest grossing Phillipine film of all time was directed by a woman. This was at its best whenever Joy was onscreen as she was perfectly played by Kathryn Bernardo and her character was well developed and interesting. On the downside, the love story and the various subplots served no purpose and detracted from the overall enjoyment with the final act falling into full-on maudlin, soap opera territory.

This is one of the best films of Modern FIlipino cinema I would say especially in the field of mainstream media. It's no surprise that the film is the highest grossing in the Philippines. I like how Joy's character and how she narrates the film through her eyes. I like how she's not ashamed to tell her job to one of her friends. I like how she's so candid in trying to keep herself whole amidst the things that try to crumble her into broken pieces. I like how she well portrays how awful and difficult it is for people like her to be steps closer in attaining her goals. This is one of Kath's best roles to date. I also like how Ethan made it a bit difficult for her to leave Hong Kong after falling into each other's intentions and vulnerabilities. What's a bit problematic though is Ethan's character especially in the beginning. It could be a little offsetting if it were to be done to girls in real life with him being a bit pushy when a girl you like is already gate keeping herself from you. But it's good that there was some character development from him going halfway through the film. It's nice he understand Joy has big plans to fulfill and he trusts they'll be together in time.Love is really the most complicated thing. It makes you question if your own dreams are really worth giving up if you can have another one with the person you love. It makes you question what road God has paved to you. But in the end you'll realize that your destiny is what your freewill desires anyway. If dreams are worth fighting for, love can find a way to be a part of it in the end.

"Isn't that how its supposed to be? When you love, all or nothing. If you hold back, then why love at all?"Hello, Love, Goodbye is my first Filipino film! I've been looking forward to this one for a while. I gotta say though, I think I prefer Wong Kar Wai's portrayal of Hong Kong to Cathy Garcia-Molina's. Hello, Love, Goodbye tells a very standard love story that's been done numerous times before, and better. A couple meets for a short amount of time in a foreign country, and then are parted by time. This film is incredibly soap-opera esque, and there are a lot of scenes with heavy over-acting and some delicious scenery chewing. The audio mixing is also all over the place. The actors can usually be heard fine, but sometimes the music drowns out what they are saying during important scenes. Some of the dialogue is also really unintentionally hilarious, like the scene where a character is berated for opening a bar instead of becoming a doctor or store manager. No offense to anyone out there, but I would probably be more impressed with someone who opened their own restaurant than someone who manages a Walgreens The pacing is also all over the place, and the film is way too long for what its trying to accomplish. There are some genuinely sweet moments hidden amidst the saccharine sea that is Hello, Love, Goodbye, but I couldn't help but feel that this movie is frighteningly similar to those "inspirational/romantic" YouTube videos that get roasted from time to time.If you're looking for a light, modern-pop romance film, you could do a lot worse than Hello, Love, Goodbye. It's silly, but sincere. I personally struggled to care about this movie strongly, but I promise there are some really nice moments scattered throughout. I think there is a really good movie buried in here, but it'll take some work to unearth it.

There’s a constant struggle among love, family, and dreams. As Filipinos, we already grew up taking this huge responsibility to give back to our parents once we land a stable job and earn something to sustain ourselves and the needs of our family. We need to adhere to this concern because the breadwinners were sometimes deprived to live their dreams because of the unexpected weight of responsibility we carry once we earn a degree.In addition, there’s a heavy feeling after watching this film. It took a while for me to process things and calm myself from crying. A good mix of Kathryn and Alden. Their tandem is an interesting one.

March Around The World 2022 (7/30)I, for some reason, thought this was a bog standard cheesy rom-com, and I put it on my potential watch list for this challenge because I knew I had some others with kind of heavy subject matter and wanted a few lighter options in the mix too. Cut to 20 minutes from the end and I am sobbing, SOBBING! Not what I was expecting at all. I'll be honest, Ethan's initial pursuit of Joy is maybe questionable, and judging by the most popular review for this film, a lot of people could not see past that, which is a shame, I think. Once the characters actually connect properly this is a really sweet and lovely romance. And as much time as that romance does take up, it's not at the expense of Joy as a character. She is always at the centre of this story, which is about so much more than a really quite cute love story. I wasn't familiar at all with the cultural setting here, but I think there's enough context for everything that it's very easy to understand the employment situations, as well as the family commitments, and all the stress and pressure that comes with that. Joy and Ethan's situations are different but they're a result of the same social, economic and familial restrictions/obligations, and these things hang over their romance the whole time, which adds a layer of urgency and also sadness to them both. There's a scene pretty early on with Joy on a bus, and she bumps into an old college friend, there on his honeymoon, and it's just devastating. I knew at that point this wasn't the film I was expecting it to be. Kathryn Bernardo is quietly heartbreaking in that scene, and she really does centre this entire film. And later when she realises that she's been working towards an unattainable goal for her family, and now she finally gets to have a choice of what happens to her but it's not as simple as she hoped it might be, I was so invested in her that my heart was simultaneously soaring for her, while also breaking. There's one or two little things in here that keep it from being 5 stars, but if you can see past Ethan's somewhat questionable initial pursuit of Joy then there's a really beautiful film here.

The highest grossing Filipino film of all time (not counting inflation).It’s pretty bland, uninspired, and very cliche-driven film. There’s not really a lot to say about it. The most interesting aspect of this otherwise heinous picture is its idealized portrait of OFW life, which opens questions that are not only timely, but important discussions that need to be had about the Philippine economy and its foreign relations.The love story is also forgettable. I didn’t feel a single shred of compatibility between Alden Richards and Kathryn Bernardo, despite Bernardo being a memorable actress. The love story can effectively be removed and it would be a better whole. I’ve just seen too much of these horrendous love formulas spanning the pre-war era to be moved by a stale production.

A good romance/drama set in Hong Kong where the main character is working as a domestic helper to help her family back home in the Philippines. As the months get closer to her moving for new opportunities in Canada, she meets a bartender also from the Philippines and as they get closer, has to decide whether to stay or go.While the romantic drama was a little too much for me in some parts, it was awesome to see a movie centered around characters representing the overseas population from the Philippines, who probably make up the largest foreign population in Hong Kong.I loved the non-cliche ending and the characters were likable. It is also the current highest-grossing film from the Philippines of all time, which is pretty awesome!

I think ito na ang extent ng pagiging experimental ng Star Cinema, lol.First and foremost, Kathryn Bernardo proved once again that she can evoke whatever emotion she wants from her audience. She acts with her eyes, body language, speech tone, just overflowing with passion! Nakakadala ang performance niya!I don't quite get why every single major family in the film had a member who had some sory of disability. It didn't really contribute anything to the story's development nor was it even explored through dialogue. It felt like an easy excuse to elicit sympathy from the viewers, which is problematic as PWDs have been forever subject to being accessorized in films and tv.Wasn't a fan of Alden's character. Too shallow imo. However, Alden himself did a great job in matching Kathryn's splendid acting! He was decent enough to keep me engaged.Played it safe on the ending. Of course, it had to have even a tinge of a happy ending because it is a mainstream film and lots of Filipinos consider a film bad if it doesn't have a light or a positive-leaning ending. It was building up nicely to an emotional climax but the moment Joy and Ethan had that confrontation scene, everything that followed felt like an attempt to repair the sad atmosphere that it produced. I wish the film maximized that misery and took a full-on drama end. Maybe then it would have more impact.Technicalities were subpar. The film did not look aesthetically pleasing most of the time. Perhaps it wanted to portray the gritty experience of living as a DH in HK, but it could have been better. Score utterly sucked. The audience does not need to hear a full track while the scenes transpire. This is not a music video.Tolerable, for sure. Kathryn carried it.

"The time stops when you don't use it."A heartfelt romantic comedy drama set in Hong Kong following the story of Joy and Ethan, two filipino immigrants. Its not a new story, but it blends the hardships, sacrifice, dreams, love & realities of a overseas domestic worker quite empathetically. The pairing of Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards was so charming & sweet.Hello, Love, Goodbye‘s message is simple: give yourself the chance to do what you want, get back up from disappointments, be courageous enough to love and choose whether you want to leave or stay. The film doesn’t portray Bernardo and Alden as some people who need your pity—but rather portrays the characters humanely, with stories and experiences that empower them to ultimately choose how to pave their own way for their futures—with or without each other. A warm satisfying drama.(ending made me ugly cry lol)Alden Richards<333333333333

This film emanates comfort, uncertainty, and self-worth. And that is what Philippine cinema should put out not hundreds of generic cringy-ass rom-com films. Joy, a struggling Filipino DH, who has specific dreams for herself and her family meets Ethan who doesn't exactly know what he wants. A literal manifestation of the 'Grumpy x Sunshine' trope, and I'm here for it. Joy finds comfort in Ethan, even if she isn't exactly looking for a relationship.Amid their emerging relationship, Ethan finds himself filled with uncertainty as his time with Joy comes close to its end. He deeply hopes that Joy will change her mind as he planned everything out for their future. But this is where it gets tricky, Joy has already made up her mind, from the start. She knows what she wants, even Ethan can't change her mind. And I support and understand her. All her life, she has put her family first, and this time she needs to prioritize herself. Ethan does not deserve Joy's half-self if she even chooses to stay, cause she will always have 'what ifs' and that would also be unfair for Ethan.In simple terms, Joy needs to find herself. To feel that she is her own person. Only then will she be able to give herself committedly to Ethan, and he understood that in the end.This is when two persons respect each other's dreams and are both willing to let go of each other to grow individually and come back when they're both ready.Alden & Kath > Kathniel, I still stand by this.

a kathryn bernardo stan through and throughnot the first time i've seen this so i always knew ethan's character is so problematic, but i guess that's a point to be made so the development can have more depth. a guy who's immature and foolish and always putting his heart above all else, learning that letting go is another form of loving when all he'd ever known is to go for what he can reach if it makes him happy, and a girl that lived her life so small and consuming due to the sacrifices needed to be made at every corner, finding the kind of love that presented her the choice that could be the turning point of everything. in ethan, she found the strength to choose herself. in joy, he found a love that encourages him to be more.it was questionable and doomed from the start, but if i know anything about love, it's that enough of it can really be the euphoria you need in your darkest, heaviest days. at the end, finding each other made them better. and with just that, none of the love was lost.

Philippines' highest grossing film. It's good, for the most part. There's a lot more here than I expected. There's some interesting socio-political and cultural commentary here about Overseas Filipino Workers' economic conditions living in Hong-Kong but it's all wrapped up in an overly melodramatic tone which I don't totally jive with. Kathryn Bernardo—who is fantastic in this btw—singing as badly as I did when playing SingStar on the PS2 is a highlight of this film.

#stoprussiai used to avoid this movie like the plague out of fear that i might get the unnecessary and unsolicited feels, but after several years i am happy to report that i was only able to see the movie for what it was and did not (un)intentionally project my personal experiences into what the film portrayedi could say that my goals are much more defined now, and what i want out of a deeper connection from a person is clearer, one that gives me a certain sense of agency; not marred by deception, mindfuckery, or misguided intentions; nor should it amplify my weaknesses more than my (unfounded) potentialchoosy na kung choosy ;)

Dari judulnya kupikir film ini tentang cinta-cintaan klise dengan latar luar negeri. IH TAPI TERNYATA... Ketampar abis. Heeeeiiii film ini ternyata bagussss. Seenggaknya menurutku.Kathryn Bernardo di sini bener-bener mirip Ayu Ting-Ting. Eh, nggak. Yang bener Kathryn Bernardo di sini bener-bener berpenampilan cewek biasa-biasa aja, yang masuk ke karakternya. Di sini dia berperan jadi Joy, lulusan S1 yang kesulitan dapat kerja. Dia ngerantau ke Hongkong, berpikiran mau kerja apa aja yang penting dapat uang. Karena mau hijrah ke Kanada jadi perawat dan ngeboyong keluarganya hidup sejahtera di sana. Dia nggak ada waktu buat senang-senang, termasuk buat cinta-cintaan. Kerja kerja kerja mulu. Sampai akhirnya ada cowok datang ke dalam hidupnya, pengen deketin dia tapi dia nggak mau nggak mau nggak mau. Nggak bermaksud jual mahal, tapi dia memang nggak punya waktu buat pacaran.Aku suka film ini. Aku tau rasanya jadi Joy, terutama pas dia yang kerja sama orang Hongkong. Aku pernah kerja sama orang Chinese dan keras sih dunia kerjanya. Simple-nya mereka ngomong kayak marah-marah padahal sebenarnya ngomong biasa aja. Ketika ngelakuin kesalahan kecil, mereka bisa marahnya gedeeeeee banget. Aku nggak bermaksud rasis lho ini ya.Interaksinya Joy dan si cowok di mana si cowok nggak gentar deketin. Disuruh pergi ajaaaa nggak pengen pacaran ya bebal tetap aja dekat, ngingatin aku sama ayangku. Dulu dia juga gitu ke aku, ketika aku malasssss banget buat pacaran karena nggak mau sakit hati lagi buang-buang waktu bikin aku selama ini nggak produktif, dia tetap aja maju.Aku mau fokus kerja aja, karena ketika aku galau karena pacar ya bisa ambyar kerjaanku. Singkatnya ini film tentang orang miskin itu nggak bisa milih. Nggak punya pilihan. Termasuk mau pilih wujudin cita-cita atau cinta. Sediiiiiiih. Orang miskin nggak bisa 'egois'

Ang dami kong nabasa at narinig na rave reviews ng pelikula na ito kaya na delay ang panonood ko. And that was one of the worst decision I made. I think I found my most favorite Cathy Garcia Molina movie. This is her best work. And Kathryn, wow! I think I found a new respect to you as an actor.Some of my favorites:1. Cinematography - grabe ang ganda ng pag capture sa Hong Kong and how it tells the story of our domestic helpers2. The setting helped in the storytelling, hindi lang siya background. 3. JOY AND HER CHOICE AS A WOMAN - galit talaga ako sa mga babaeng character sa pelikula ni CGM but Joy gave me so much joy. How she insisted that she needs to decide for herself and her happiness. This is cinema! Chos. Add the scene where the character of Cacai asked the question about women being selfish when she choose herself!Mga not so favorite:- Fat jokes! Talaga ba?- The neverending family struggle. I guess it will not be a star cinema movie if there's no conflict with the family. Kaya nga hindi na resolve na domestic abuse victim ang nanay ni Joy. Because there's too many family drama!!! - Medyo makulit si Ethan when he courted JoyOverall, this was really a great movie. Please Kathryn, continue making this kind of movie and choosing this type of character. You have a new fan in me.

Cathy Garcia-Molina has setback my generation of Filipinos as well as our cinema  A few notes I took during the movie:- Off-putting editing, too many random cuts, does not allow shots to breathe as well as having unnecessary ones.- Random foreigner actors? Lousy English dialogue.- Suspense was ruined in one scene that was the same as shown in beginning. Legit ruined the character reveal.- Kathryn Bernardo’s acting performance was respectable and well done. First half of the movie made me lose my mind and would have end up giving this film a 2 star or below if it continued. Second half made up for it, it kind of got me in my feels.Overall, I can understand why people enjoy this film, but if it’s the dominating genre in my country, we are doomed.+ highest-grossing local film of all-time in the Philippines?!FALSE IMAGERY OF LOVE WILL RUIN MY GENERATION!*note: I am half-serious.

I am really not a fan of some of the tropes some Filipino films showcase, particularly the man harrasing a woman into giving him a chance. If that were entirely out of the picture, I would have rated this higher. That said, despite that, this was a pleasant surprise. Kathryn was a powerhouse performer. I had low expectations for Alden but I wasn't at all disappointed. They made a familiar though not personally relatable story of the OFW feel personal to me.Lastly, a not-bad movie gets even better when they go with a great ending, which this one had, in my opinion.

แรกเห็นโปสเตอร์ที่อยู่ในแอพเมเจอร์ ตอนเลื่อนผ่านเจอว่ามีฉายแค่ไม่กี่ที่ หนึ่งในนั้นคือสาขาเอสพลานาดรัชดา ก็ไม่ได้สนใจอะไร ด้วยไม่ได้หาข้อมูลมาก่อน บวกกับสีหวานใสของโปสเตอร์ที่เห็น ก็ไม่ได้ดึงดูดอะไรเท่าไหร่ จนรู้ว่ามันเป็นหนังที่ทำรายได้ถล่มทลายในประเทศบ้านเกิดอย่าง ฟิลิปปินส์ และเนื้อหาข้างในนั้นมีอะไรมากกว่าหนังโรแมนติก(โปสเตอร์)สีลูกกวาด ธรรมดาๆ เลยลองหาข้อมูลเพิ่มเติมอีกนิดหน่อย ทั้งดูหนังตัวอย่าง และเช็คข้อมูลในเว็ป IMDb ถึงรู้ว่าหนังได้เข้าชิงรางวัล Best Asian Film ในเวที Australian Academy of Cinema & Television Arts (AACTA) ประจำปีล่าสุดด้วยหนังเปิดเรื่องด้วยเสียงบรรยาย พร้อมภาพกิจวัตรประจำวันของ จอย ฟาเบรกัส (แคธริน เบอร์นาร์โด) หญิงสาวชาวฟิลิปปินส์ ที่มาขายแรงงานอยู่ในฮ่องกง เพื่อโดยใช้วีซ่าทำงาน (ที่ฮ่องกงจะให้สิทธิ์แรงงานต่างชาติทำได้แค่งาน “แม่บ้าน” เท่านั้น) โดยหวังว่าสักวันหนึ่งจะเก็บเงินได้มากพอที่จะเดินทางไปยังแคนาดา ที่ที่เธอจะสามารถทำงาน “พยาบาล” อย่างที่เรียนจบมาเพื่อผลตอบแทนที่เธอคู่ควร และสามารถขอวีซ่าถาวรที่จะส่งผลดีต่อครอบครัวเธออันประกอบไปด้วยพ่อ (ที่ประสบอุบัติเหตุจนทำงานไม่ได้) และน้องชายกับน้องสาวอีกอย่างละหนึ่งคน ให้ได้เดินทางมาอยู่ด้วยกันอย่างพร้อมหน้าในสักวัน ส่วนแม่ของเธอก็ต้องลงทุนแต่งงานกับชาวฮ่องกง เพื่อหวังว่าสักวันหนึ่งหากได้วีซ่าถาวรแล้วจะสามารถพาทุกคนที่รออยู่ที่ฟิลิปปินส์มาอยู่ด้วยกันได้เช่นกันช่วง 5-10 นาทีแรกนี้ หนังใช้วิธีตัดภาพฉึบฉับ ราวกับเป็นหนังแอ็คชั่นหรือทริลเลอร์ เพื่อสื่อให้เห็นถึงความวุ่นวาย กับการพยายามขวนขวายทำทุกอย่างที่สามารถหาเงินมาให้ได้มากที่สุด ซึ่งแน่นอนว่างานแม่บ้านอย่างเดียวไม่สามารถให้ค่าตอบแทนที่เพียงพออยู่แล้ว เธอจึงต้องแหกกฏด้วยการแอบทำงานอื่นที่วีซ่าของเธอไม่รองรับด้วยกระทั่งวันหนึ่ง การเข้ามาของ อีธาน (อัลเดน ริชาร์ด) บาร์เทนเดอร์หนุ่มสุดหล่อ ที่คบสาวแบบไม่จริงจัง จนเพื่อนๆต้องตั้งชื่อเรียกสาวๆเหล่านั้นว่า “มิสวันจันทร์, มิสอังคาร, ฯลฯ” แรกเริ่ม อีธานก็เหมือนจะเห็น จอย เป็นแค่ผู้หญิงพวกนั้น แต่ทีละน้อยที่ต่างมีเหตุให้ได้ปรับทุกข์กันในแค่ไม่กี่วันที่ได้เจอ ดูเหมือนความรู้สึกของเขาจะหนักแน่นมากกว่าเก่า ตรงข้ามกับจอย ที่เธอไม่มีเวลาแม้แต่จะนอนในแต่ละวันด้วยซ้ำ การคิดถึงเรื่องความรัก จึงนับว่าแทบไม่อยู่ในสมองของเธอเลยสักนิดหนังมีจุดเด่นอยู่ที่บทภาพยนตร์ ซึ่งทีมผู้เขียนบททั้งสาม (คาร์มี่ เรย์มันโด, โรนาลิซ่า เอ. โค่ และ เคธีย์ การ์เซีย-โมลิน่า ซึ่งควบเก้าอี้ผู้กำกับ อีกตำแหน่งหนึ่งด้วย) ดูจะเข้าใจขนบของหนังแนวนี้อย่างทะลุปรุโปร่ง ท่ามกลางดราม่าที่คุกรุ่นและอึมครึมอยู่ในตัวละคร จอย - นางเอกของเรื่องมาตั้งแต่ฉากแรก จึงมีการใช้เสน่ห์ ของพระเอกอย่าง อีธาน เข้ามาค่อยๆปรับมู๊ดของหนังให้ค่อยๆเดินทางไปอยู่ในเขตของความเป็นหนังรักอย่างไม่รีบเร่ง โดยมีตัวช่วยเป็นบรรดาเพื่อนๆ ทั้งฝั่งของจอย และเพื่อนของอีธาน เข้ามาเป็นกองหนุนในการแจกจ่ายรอยยิ้ม เสียงหัวเราะ และมุกตลกต่างๆในหนัง ให้อบอวลไปด้วยบรรยากาศของการเป็นหนังรอมคอม (โรแมนติก/คอมเมดี้) ในแบบพอดิบพอดี ไม่ยัดเยียด และไม่ล้นเกินไปในแต่ละฉาก ส่วนผสมต่างๆเหล่านี้ บวกกับฉากหลังที่เป็นเมืองกึ่งโรแมนติก กึ่งเหงาอยู่แล้วของฮ่องกง การกำกับภาพที่งดงามและสื่อความตามอารมณ์ของเรื่องในแต่ละช่วง กับเพลงและดนตรีประกอบ ที่แม้จะคลออยู่แทบตลอดเรื่อง จนอาจฟังดูบิ้วท์อารมณ์จนเกินพอดี แต่เมื่อทั้งหมดประกอบรวมอยู่ด้วยกัน มันกลับกลายเป็นความพอดีที่เหมาะเจาะลงตัว เช่นเดียวกับที่ความรักของจอย กับอีธาน ค่อยๆ ก่อตัวขึ้นทีละน้อย เมื่อเวลาล่วงเลยไปถึงอย่างนั้น หนังเองก็ไม่ได้ละเลย หรือปล่อยทิ้งประเด็นดราม่าที่ปูมาตั้งแต่แรกไปเสียเฉยๆ ตรงกันข้าม มันกลับถูกนำกลับมาใช้อย่างถูกที่ถูกเวลาในช่วงไคลแม็กซ์สำคัญท้ายเรื่อง ปมที่เคยถูกเกริ่นไว้ในตอนแรก ถูกคลี่คลาย และอธิบายในอีกมุมมองหนึ่งที่คนดูอาจลืมนึกไป เช่นความจริงในมุมของแม่ของจอย (มาริเซล ลักซา) กับการที่ต้องแต่งงานกับชายอื่นตามความต้องการของสามี เพื่อหวังให้เธอช่วยเหลือครอบครัวในช่วงชีวิตอันยากลำบาก, หรือการพาคนดูไปพบกับความจริงอีกด้านของ อีธาน เอง ที่ต้นเรื่องเหมือนเขาจะเป็นเพียงหนุ่มเสเพล บริหารเสน่ห์เล่นไปวันๆ จริงๆแล้วก็มีปมปัญหาทั้งด้านครอบครัวและความรักไม่แพ้ตัวของจอยเองด้วยดังนั้นเมื่อถึงจุดที่หนังพาไปพบกับสิ่งที่สองตัวละครหลักต้องเจอ เผชิญหน้า และนำไปสู่การหาทางออกของกันและกัน สิ่งที่สำคัญที่สุด ณ ขณะนั้น จึงไม่ใช่เพียงแค่เรื่องของ “ความรัก” อีกแล้ว หากแต่เป็น “ความเข้าใจ” ต่างหาก ไม่ต้องสงสัยเลยว่า เมื่อผ่านอะไรต่อมิอะไรกันมามากมายขนาดนั้น ทั้งสองคนจะรักกันมากแค่ไหน หากแต่ที่ยังไม่สามารถหาบทสรุปให้กับปลายทางความสัมพันธ์ของทั้งคู่ได้นั้น คือพวกเขาเข้าใจกันและกันมากพอหรือยัง เคารพสิทธิ์และการตัดสินใจของอีกฝ่ายมากกว่าเลือกที่จะยึดเอาความต้องการของตัวเองเป็นที่ตั้งหรือเปล่า?ซีเควนซ์สุดท้ายของหนังจึงเป็นอะไรที่พิเศษมาก มันทำให้เราทั้งอบอุ่นหัวใจ เศร้า และแอบหวั่นใจไปพร้อมๆ กัน แต่เมื่อนั่นคือหนทางที่ตัวละครทั้งสองตัดสินใจแล้วว่ามันต้องเป็น สิ่งที่เราในฐานะคนดูทำได้ก็เพียงแค่ต้องเข้าใจ เพราะนั่นมันคือสิทธิ์ในการตัดสินใจใช้ชีวิตของพวกเขาเอง เหมือนที่พวกเขาเข้าใจและต่างก็ยอมรับในทางเลือกของกันและกันได้จริงๆ

A story in two layers. The first is with Joy and her experiences as a Filipino overseas domestic helper living in Hong Kong. We not only delve into her journey of wanting a better life for her and her family, but we also get a glimpse of this particular subculture of Filipinos living in Hong Kong, who have carved out a little community for themselves away from their home. Between poor pay, long hours of work, and shuffling through countless jobs and hustles to make ends meet, seeing these workers come together to host their own makeshift beauty pageant, or weeping together as they're watching Filipino dramas on someone's phone while they're in the middle of illegally peddling retail, it's those small moments of solidarity that adds a charming touch. It adds an extra dimension to this life that isn't just all doom, gloom, and abuse (and sadly there's a lot of it) to make you sympathize with their struggle.The second layer is a Wattpad fueled, Twilight charged romance full of the same toxic tropes with the weird stalking and complete disregard for boundaries. They made sure to make Ethan seem like such a bad boy who can get any woman he wants (and they display this by his friends joking around about how all his flings are named after a day in the week), yet he drops them all for Joy because...I don't know actually. Maybe it's at this crucible where a bachelor--who has no reason to like a woman who doesn't come from money--suddenly becoming obsessed with her that people find truly romantic, but then he admits to later gaslighting and manipulating her the entire time towards the end (but he did it for love!).That cute montage of them taking selfies all over iconic landmarks in Hong Kong while a Filipino ballad lulls in the background, is supposed to ignite lots of warm feelings in the belly, but for those who didn't buy into this relationship, can feel misplaced. The only part of the romance I liked were Joy and Ethan's friends cheering their relationship on. Others may see them as one dimensional who act as nothing but cheerleaders, but these Filipino romances know how to make really damn great cheerleading supporting characters that makes you wish you had them in your life. Now if only these male leads can actually be decent guys for once.

There's something deeply depressing about stumbling across a boy you loved in the past inside a crowded train, who's there with his pregnant wife. And having to tell him "I ended up like my mother after all."This movie started out so strong, but as it began to focus on their love story I just couldn't bring myself to be invested in it. The male lead was honestly immature and did not carry as much depth as the female MC. And I kept wanting to explore more of her history and depth. I honestly wish the movie was longer, enough that we could see her family, friends and their stories more. They clearly have their own stories that are reminiscent of all the Non-chinese hongkongers who sacrifice everything to suffer in a foreign nation for money. The opening montage is so good and reminded of Kimi No Nawa's.And I loved that I could trace the geography of my country in this movie. Either way, this movie was so so good.

Wow. This movie was just wow. I loved the very emotional and real way the movie discussed choosing between the love of your life and the love for your life. I also loved how the difficulties and expectations women face in society were discussed through Joy, her cousin, her friends, her employer(s), and her mother. What a phenomenal movie. The quote “Is love only expressed through sacrifice?” Is something that’s going to stick with me FOR SURE.

Let's continue the anti-love theme formula.Ang ganda. Sa trend ng movies na lumalabas ngayon, its one of the decent ones. Una, kase nag-work yung Alden-Kathryn team up. Pangalawa, kahit napapansin kong most Filipino romcoms ay may storyline na nagaganap sa ibang bansa, napansin kong never pumunta sa ibang lugar yung mga characters. Like yung buong film, sa Hong Kong. Mapwera lang dun sa scenes sa bahay nila Kathryn which is sobrang minimal. Third, naramdaman ko. Mas madaling hanapan ng simpatya yung mga characters ni Joy at Ethan. Mga nagsusumikap para sa pamilya, mga nagpupursiging matupad pangarap nila, mga nagmamahal pero may tamang limitations. Like sobrang ganda ng growth ni Ethan. Sobrang earned.
Ang choice, para lang sa may pera.

At nakakatuwa na hindi tanga sa pag-ibig si Joy. Tama 'yan , 'wag magpaka-tanga sa lalaki. Ang simple lang din ng story, pero ang ayos talaga ng execution niya sa film. Tapos ang ayos ng ending, na pinili nilang mahalin muna yung mga sarili nila.

“May mga tao na dumadaan lang..” A tale of star-crossed lovers in an OFW setting who met in Hong Kong. Now having found one another, they must choose in keeping their relationship or chasing after their dreams. Ang masasabi ko lang, ang saket. Ganito kami naghiwalay ng ex ko, whom I consider to be my greatest love. Siguro if kami pa neto I wouldn’t be able to watch this or be able to appreciate this sincerely (or baka nakipagbreak na ako, haha)Overall, I wish we could make more Filipino rom-coms where the two protagonists are stuck in this choice of their career or themselves. It’s such a realistic and relevant concept tbh

In all honesty, this could have been better if the film focused more on the struggles and reality of becoming a domestic helper in HongKong rather than the romance of the two characters. Ethan, the male lead, was so infuriating at times during the movie. He only had his redemption arc at the last 14 minutes of the movie. Joy, on the other hand, literally carried this movie. Her acting was really great and I could really feel her emotions during the scenes. As I said before, this would be better without the romance. I couldn’t root for the guy because he border-lined harassed the girl and manipulated/gaslighted her for choosing herself this time. Not to mention the cheesy liners that was out of place since it looked like he was invalidating her problems. I am genuinely happy with the ending and I am glad that this became a hit in the Philippines because I am tired of the culture that romanticizes struggles as long as you are together.

ang choice para sa mayayaman. Hello, Love, Goodbye perfectly portrayed the stories of OFWs in Hong Kong. Working as an OFW wasn't a choice. They had to, at the cost of their dreams. At the cost of what they could have been. Cheating. Marriage of convenience. Leaving your family behind. These have now become a norm in the OFW culture and society when it shouldn't be. It's a bitter reality of what you would do for your loved ones just to bring them up a level higher on the economic ladder. Being selfish is okay. Choosing to chase for your dreams and to find yourself is okay. Because love alone cannot solely support two people. Can love feed you when you're broke? NO. How could you add one more person in your life when you can barely take care of yourself, right?Anyway, highest respect for all the Joy Marie Fabregas out there. I aspire to be as strong as her.

Hello, Love, Goodbye revolves around the lives of Joy and Ethan; both are Filipino workers based in Hong Kong. Joy is a domestic helper who dreams of working as a nurse in Canada while Ethan is a bartender who is waiting out his permanent residency. Just like how most romantic films go, these two characters meet, fall in love, then… life happens.Hello, Love, Goodbye not just a love story, it’s a life story. About making a choice between love and chasing after your dream. Joy, as the breadwinner, works hard to give herself and her family a better life. She also actively engages in her buy-and-sell business every sunday, and even takes on a second job at night as a waitress. She desperately needs funds not only to send back home, but also to finance her dream of flying off to Canada to practice nursing, her original course. Ethan, on the other hand, is on the road to redemption after letting down his own family. He was supposed to have gained Hong Kong residency already but he left and went to the US to pursue a girl he loved. They broke up and he had to go back to zero in Hong Kong. One is burdened by her family while also committed to her dreams, the other tethered to the idea of making amends to the people closest to him, and a relationship is the last thing they need in their lives.Point of the story was about making choices, no matter how difficult they may be. Joy said “choice is only for the rich.” And she is partly correct. Choice is a luxury only the privileged can afford. It is true that not all of us can have a fair opportunity in life, that’s why when we had a chance we should make sure to grab it and used it. Joy, in the end, realized that she also has to think of herself first and made her own choices for herself, even if it means that she can’t be with Ethan. And it’s not selfish to choose your priorities first, since no one can fully understand your decisions even they say so. Choosing yourself is not an act of “selfishness”. No matter how many reasons you may have to stay and give up on your dreams—even if these include people you love the most—in the end, choosing yourself is still the most fulfilling decision you can do. Of course, if I am in the position of Ethan, I will also do everything for Joy to stay, but we can’t control everything. Sometimes loving someone also means giving them wings to explore horizons of growth.

A romance different enough from the formula to make it interesting yet close enough to keep it undeniably familiar.The first third of the film was filled with much promise, dipping its toes on social commentary by exploring the world of Filipino domestic helpers in Hong Kong. In the film’s first conflict, we see Joy (Kathryn Bernardo) deftly running away from police — even hiding in the garbage. This must not be her first time.Was this film going to have something to say about the Filipino diaspora?Once it begins to introduce the romance, though, it left that promise to immerse deeply in the tried-and-tested formula. Which is not such a bad thing.What’s refreshing about it is its confident departure from two-dimensional, well-defined fantasy. An attempt to re-define the ‘Star Cinema romantic film’, as it were. I once read about the ‘Star Cinema audience’ ’s rigid expectation of their movies, that they enter the theater fully expecting their ‘happily-ever-after’s and their convenient closures.* While I disagree with this sense of non-adventure, it is naïve to discount this insight significant enough to define the film-watching market for generations. Garcia-Molina’s cache is exactly in catering to this sensibility.The scene of Ethan’s (Alden Richards) introduction is as jarring to Joy as Ethan’s character is to the film. To be honest, I kept on expecting him to revert to some sort of savior trope in Joy’s life all throughout the film, even in his turn as a toxic Nice Guy in a pivotal moment further in the story. To her credit, Garcia-Molina gave Ethan the room to decide realistically and bear the weight of these choices‘ consequences.It was surprising how natural Richards was able to play Ethan. The writers forced his character to say some purely cheesy lines for the sake of saying them — as lip service to this Twitter generation — but Richards was somehow able to pull it off. And Bernardo did well enough in her turn as the headstrong Joy that I merely had to stop comparing her to Nadine Lustre and start appreciating what she was giving to the film.The chemistry was there, too, in that I could see them pulling off a dialogue-heavy romance à la THAT THING CALLED TADHANA, which is in no way easy to do. Those scenes where they were wasting time beside each other were gold.If our mainstream romance is really shaping up to this mold — influenced by the efforts of Antoinette Jadaone, Dan Villegas, Sigrid Bernardo, and others from the independent scene — then I’m definitely looking forward to more pleasantly-surprising, insightful entertainment.—*Don Jaucian, “How Black Sheep is trying to ‘disrupt’ Philippine cinema,” https://www.cnnphilippines.com/life/entertainment/Film/2019/6/4/black-sheep-films-interview.html

i am sick, i have a cough, it's 3 am, and i mostly screamed at the top of my lungs ONLY during the first half of this movie. only the first half. no more than the first half. and i still half-regret those pillow-screams because i think my cough is a lot worse than it was roughly 117 minutes ago. being ph's highest-grossing movie ever, i've given myself the expectations of this being quite the questionable, predictable, formulaic, cheesy, on-the-nose, and all the more problematic typical romantic flick that this was reviewed to be, and ended up being. and yet, the crazy thing was they really got me in the first half, and i got what they were giving me (some screams, some pillow punching, some inevitable cringing on corny lines but i was smiling the whole time), so that's at least a mission success.

Kathryn’s talent is way beyond her years but she can’t just carry the entire film on her own.Still don’t understand how mainstream Filipino films have a common fetish of basing an entire film abroad without illuminating its sociopolitical and cultural nuances. Can plots please have another personality besides relishing in xenocentrism? Our country has so much to offer, not to say that filming abroad is outright worthy of condemnation. At least work hard and present matters about that country that people already know off the top of their heads.It has the sincerity of people in a photo-booth posing against a green screen. Sayang. I enjoyed how they showed the plight of domestic helpers in Hong Kong, but the machismo of Alden’s character and the dry jokes rendered it an unenjoyable watch.Women shouldn’t have to sacrifice their progress for a man, any man, whether it be her father, a billionaire, or a misogynist deadbeat who professes his undying love for her.The score was incredibly tacky.We need more films about the Filipino diaspora.

I appreciate the premise and how it's been told. The realities of being an OFW and how specific it is in the context of the Filipino community in Hong Kong.What bothered me were two things:1. Is a preference thing, but Alden and Kathryn held their own, but apparently doesn't work together for me? Chemistry is lackluster, I hate to admit it but I don't feel for them as a couple here. And it is a romance so it's kind of fundamental.2. Is a technical thing - But I was bothered how this was filmed all throughout in 16:9 ratio. I feel like it diminished the scenic appreciation for the location which is Hong Kong. It could be beautifully picturesque in a theater screen, but with the ratio it felt very TV show. This is basically me nitpicking but I would appreciate a noticeable difference with TV and movie.But overall, not a bad watch. Did it waste my time? Not really. Will I consciously choose to watch this again? To kill time, maybe. Does it deserve to be the highest grossing Filipino film? Debatable. The cast was heavily influencing for that.

There have been a number of films about the life of an overseas Filipino worker, as our country is unique to have a very significant population pursuing this route. Among these films, there are gems that stood the test of time, and probably influenced real life and further films, as we see in a scene in this film.What makes Hello, Love, Goodbye enjoyable is how effortless it presents the culture, the active and passive decisions, that OFWs take, to fulfill their purpose. While there is a wide cast of characters with their corresponding side stories, nothing feels misplaced. Maybe a few were quite less filling, the different facets and permutation of circumstances of Filipinos living abroad, provides a peek to a rich tapestry for wider stories of these characters.More than how these stories are told, as enhanced by the shot choices and camera movement that let you fall in love with the cityscapes, is the courage to not shy away from the route of the socially desired, mainstream choice.Until when though do Filipinos need to be pressured to make these choices, to enter these circumstances?

God, when will the Philippines retire the overly persistent dude wearing down the uninterested girl with his charms? This film kind of makes up for it with the sheer support radiating off both the characters later in the movie, but it, along with other well-worn cliches, threaten to wear the movie down. Thankfully, though, it doesn't. It's still very much typical Pinoy romcom, but it's also one of the best examples of the genre. There is poignancy, clear-set goals from each character, and most of all, a lack of certainty in the end of their love story. Most other films bend over backwards to provide easy answers, but this movie doesn't. Joy's young cousin doesn't overcome the hardships she faces as a newly-minted domestic helper, but she does tap out and get out of them. Joy and Ethan come together at a time in Joy's life when she is just about to leave to Canada in search of greener pastures. Discontentment and resentment fester in each of the lead's personal lives in ways that don't always go away so easily. And yet...not all solutions come clean. Hello, Love, Goodbye gets that. It as a movie has experienced true life, and despite being cornier than most, it's got its finger on the pulse of the way people love and laugh, especially when time is so fleeting. This is the best acting work on either of the two sides, Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards. A change of pace brings out the best in you, I think.

Hello, Love, Goodbye owes its strength in how well-written Joy's character is. She braved leaving the Philippines for Hong Kong to be able to provide for her family and fulfill her dream of uniting her family again. She had to sacrifice a lot of things to be able to make it a reality, yet she remained steadfast in what she wanted did even if she had to give up on love.Here, we see Kathryn at her best. And it's nice to see her paired with Alden who's able to keep up with her. Other aspects of the movie needed improvement, but Kathryn's acting prowess carried the movie through.

i’ve been putting off watching this movie for years now because when it first came out, several of my friends mentioned that joy reminded them of me.and then i noticed that netflix is removing this title tomorrow so i thought why not?hello, love, goodbye is yet another ode to our country’s unsung heroes—our overseas workers, but with a more authentic touch. it takes on new angles and anchors its narrative specifically to hong kong, which coincidentally happens to be one of my favorite places and the only country im inclined to visit more than once in my lifetime. maybe im biased.this film reminded me of my yayas my family helped to get to hong kong to seek greener pastures and my own relatives who took a gambit and flew out of the philippines to get a better shot at life as well. it spoke to me as a fellow ate / eldest sister who’d do anything for my family, even if it meant doing so at my own expense.hello, love, goodbye is an honest portrait of our culture and a reminder that we filipinos have a shared existence that transcends time and place—find comfort in that.other notes:“minsan gusto ko na lang maging selfish at iwanan lahat ng responsibilidad ko. nagagalit ako kasi parang wala akong choice.” SPOKE TO ME ON SO MANY LEVELS

somehow combines all movie + character tropes possible in the typical pinoy cinema fashion but still had me balling my eyes outthis is truly peak pinoy cinema.. beyond the portrayal of a healthy relationship (finally), i truly enjoyed the portrayal of DH workers in HK in full transparency and rawness.. especially with sending remittance back home as Kathryn also to save money (pag-ipunan) for her nursing agency to fly to Canada .. domestic labor is one of the main sources of income for many Filipino women both at home and abroad. even the opening seen, of her running away from authorities because she took an under the table job exposes the difficult reality of DH workers as they strive to make ends meet for their families back home. joy's situation is very lucky compared to other experiences I've heard of DH being abused and exploited by their bosses. other than being a film starring Kathryn Bernado and surprisingly NOT Daniel Padilla, i wonder what power this film could've had on shedding light on the exploitation, rights, and working conditions of DH workers and the "outsourcing" image we have as Filipinosanother line that truly resonated with me was when joy's ama reprimanded joy for abandoning her disabled daughter, annie, on the street.. she unable to pick her up on time.. joy's amma exclaimed, "how could you do this to her, i thought u loved her" this made me think about the complexity of love DH workers face.. in ur job description, you must love other peoples children, u care for them daily, watch them grow up, and essentially fill in this role of a parent to these children all while being miles away from your own family and often times unable to spend quality time with them for years until your contract expires.. to what extent to DH workers feel love towards the children they care for while simultaneously feeling guilt that they cannot be there for their own family or children? one possible answer in resolving these complex feelings of love, guilt, and regret is by reminding yourself your sense of purpose in which most of these DH workers find purpose in their love for their family willing to sacrifice to put food on the table and support the education of their loved ones.. YAYA is fantastic documentary that follows the life of a DH worker who in the director's, justin cheung's, words, "helped build a family at the expense of her own"

An unusual plotstory, because it is telling a love story of a Pinoy imigrant, a domestic helper in HongKong.Quite a fresh idea.Moreover, I like the ending, because it doesn't romanticized that they have to be together for the sake of love, so they sacrifice their dreams and future. In the end, Joy still chooses to go to Canada to follow her dream for a better future, and refuse to stuck in HK even though her love stay there. Yes, girl! Yes! this is Cathy Garcia's redemption after a disappointing film, The Hows of Us. I was very impressed on how they showed the struggle and working conditions of Filipino domestic helpers in Hong Kong. it even question the problems of labor export policy and the lack of opportunities and failed social services in the country. the storyline might be predictable yet it is straight to the point, and effective to touch the audiences. Star Cinema might repeatedly used their formula for a romantic-drama/comedy film but they handled it properly. the side story of Kathryn's and Alden's family are justified to be part of the story for us to understand their present decisions. the friends from both sides are only present for comedic purposes but it can be problematic as it serves distraction to the real issue. though, i appreciate the presence of Kathryn's companions who are also domestic helpers. Alden's role fell short from the very beginning and we are left with no assurance of his character development. as well, Alden's pick-up lines are so irritating and I am happy Kathryn was not doing it.above all, this is a breakthrough performance of Kathryn Bernardo as she matured to handle a strong female character and let go from her previous fragile roles. this film proves that Kathryn does not need Daniel to be recognized as a great actress.

It's not an unusual OFW love story but I liked that it's distinctly advocating for standing up for yourself, being individualistic (Joy still choosing herself & Ethan persisted on building a new chance to live a good life), and taking & earning the "2nd chances" in life. It has its problems in regards with the character Ethan (he's pushy and a bit creepy especially in the first part) but regardless, I appreciate that it is realistic to the struggles and situations of being an OFW and the relationship between the couple and the character's family dynamics as well. Thank god that Joy still chose herself in the end (regardless whether or not what happens to the two of them in the said future). Also, I think this is my favorite Kathryn Bernardo's acting so far, she really embodied the complex character of Joy.

I watched this film for my thesis, and I loved it!! It’s more than just a typical romance film because it also explored the struggles and plights that OFWs experience. Plus, it delivered a beautiful message about dreams and why we shouldn’t give up on them despite the setbacks we encounter. Ramdam na ramdam ko yung emotions ng story, and ang galing nina Kathryn at Alden dito! They gave such moving performances.However, as much as I love this film, there are some things I didn’t like:-Too many subplots, and not all of them were done well. As the film focused on Joy and Ethan’s love story, many subplots got overshadowed and lost their emotional impact. The one with Joy’s mother towards the end wasn’t even built up properly.-That fatphobic joke from Joross Gamboa’s character… seriously, was that really necessary??-There are so many disabled characters. I appreciate the representation but these disabled characters were just… there. They didn’t serve any crucial purpose apart from highlighting the difficulties in Joy and Ethan’s lives. And why is it that both of Joy and Ethan’s fathers were disabled? I get that the director may have wanted to portray them as weakened, but frankly, having both of them disabled felt forced. Also, the portrayal of Annie’s disability is stereotypical.-As other reviewers have said, Alden’s character (Ethan) is a big red flag. I feel like they could’ve written the conflict without making Ethan a red flag character — without making him disregard Joy’s dream. Also, he was creepy in the beginning. He gave off stalker vibes…-While many of the dialogues were well-written, some felt stiff and forced.-Mary Dale’s disappearance subplot was unnecessary. It came out of nowhere and lasted only for a while, which undercut the emotions. If they spent more time on it, it would’ve hit harder and would’ve really highlighted Mary Dale’s plight as an OFW.Nevertheless, despite these criticisms of mine, I really love this film! It made me smile a lot today.

Sorry, I DON'T LOVE 'Hello, Love, Goodbye' because of: (1) The story. MA... MAKATOTOHANAN. It's like the romance drama version of the 2016 MMFF Best Picture 'Sunday Beauty Queen'. So much respect for our hardworking OFWs not just in Hongkong but all over the world. You appreciate all the sacrifices they make and feel the longing and suffering they endure just to send money to their loved ones back home. (2) The cast. I've always been a fan of Alden Richards' acting skills and he certainly didn't disappoint. I initially thought the role didn't suit him based on the trailer but he just proved that he's one of the best young actors around. Talagang ramdam mo at maiiyak ka pag ginamit na nang Pambansang Bae ang mga mata niya. The supporting cast were all great from Joross Gamboa, Cacai Bautista and Lovely Abella (these 2 were riotous), MaiMai Entrata, Jeffrey Tam, Jameson Blake to veterans Lito Pimentel, Maricel Laxa-Pangilinan and William Lorenzo to even the local Hongkong actors. But it was Kathryn Bernardo who surprised me the most. She really has grown as an actress from her teleserye days. Since I choose not to see her movies with Daniel Padilla, I never expected her to be so effective and sympathetic as the young woman torn between following her own dreams over love. I thought this was more of her movie than Alden's. (3) The soundtrack. Moira, Moira, Moira. Just hearing her voice in 'Kung 'Di Rin Lang Ikaw' and 'Ikaw At Ako' gave me goosebumps. And these 2 songs were the perfect soundtrack to Ethan and Joy's love story. (4) The setting. Who would've thought that the busy streets of urban Hongkong would look beautiful on the big screen. Kudos to the cinematographer.But if I were to nitpick, it would be that the hugot lines were too many. Joy and Ethan mouthing them all off sometimes felt forced just for the viewers to remember and quote them when they talk about the movie. Nonetheless, ang pelikulang ito ay MA... MASAKIT SA PUSO pero MA... MAGANDANG-MAGANDA. So sorry, I don't love this movie because... I REALLY LOVED it.

It's kind of easy to see why Hello, Love, Goodbye was one of the Philippine's highest grossing films until very recently. It's a romance. The movie it dethroned for highest grossing was also a romance movie, and the one that took its place is also largely a romance (with some time travel thrown in). People love love, but they also love the drama and everything else that comes with it. —And boy does Hello, Love, Goodbye have a lot going on. Overwrought emotions, situations with dire circumstances played to dramatic background music, a reluctant at first romance, and so on. Some of this works, I think a romance needs some high stakes and emotionality, some of it falls flat however and doesn't work. I never felt too compelled by the relationship between Joy and Ethan, so the fact that it could've ended at any time was never really upsetting to me. Mostly the movie was just fun, a little silly at times, and the writing could've had another pass but it was an okay watch and more than distracting enough.

As the once highest grossing film in all of Philippine history, I was genuinely surprised that HLG interacted with the overseas foreign worker (OFW) problem that has become an omnipresent yet taboo subject. However, HLG’s pitfall is ironically the subject it tries to interact with. HLG portrays a tragic, Shakespearian romance as a result of the OFW problem instead of holding up a mirror to its audience and asking why have we let it become the norm in Filo culture that our children must sacrifice their own autonomy to provide for their family? Also (I can’t believe I’m advocating for men) but Ethan is so creepy in this movie, can we please have some non-asshole Filipino male representation on-screen for once pls <3

Immigrants, OFWs, women, and most especially first-born daughters I am honestly raving about this not solely because of the love story, but due to its representation of the aforementioned groups. Despite being privileged with a good life provided by my parents, I still encounter similar struggles, even in minor ways. This makes me ponder how people who have endured worse or comparable experiences truly feel.I believe this film isn't among the highest-grossing due to its love story, but because it resonated deeply with Filipinos. It's challenging to find representations of Filipino struggles in mainstream cinema; most Filipino movies lack such depictions as they primarily focus on love or "kilig." Despite this film containing elements of romance, I'll take what I can get.

One of the best Filipino films I've ever watched. Admittedly at first I thought it would be just like any other usual Filipino romance films with a dash of cringe, so when I finally saw it on Netflix about 2 years ago, it came as a pleasant surprise. Kathryn and Alden's superb performances matched with their palpable chemistry were enough to convince me that this film is worth loving. Plus, I admire the depth the actors gave to their characters and I really felt that they were truly immersed and embodied their characters very well. Also, HLG gave me a peek into the lives of our kababayans, especially of Domestic Helpers in Hongkong. Re-watching it today with my mom made me appreciate the movie even more. It's now my La La Land.Hoping for HLG Part 2!

HINDI MO KAILANGANG I-SOLVE ANG MGA PROBLEMA NI JOY SHE CAN HANDLE IT ON HER OWN SHE'S BEEN HANDLING IT ON HER OWN BEFORE MO SIYA BIGYAN NG INUMIN BWISET KA !!! kinda creepythis movie has a really good ost napapakanta ako i love it nicenice and WTH ANG GANDA NG CASTING! lalo na 'yong mga kapatid ni alden omg bentang-benta sa akin like magkakamukha talaga sila!?!?! ++ 'yong dimples grabe please sobrang amazed akosabi ko nga sa tropa ko while watching: NAKAKA-CULTURE SHOCK!! hindi ako sanay na kayang bumato ng linya ng kaeksena ni kathryn. i mean, oo naman hindi sila magka-tier when it comes to acting pero kung icocompare kay japanese tumbong PLEASE i love it. favorite line from alden: "kasi if you hold back, ba't nagmahal ka pa?" hehepero story-wise :') hay... i want kathryn in a movie na walang sprinkle ng romance. kaya niya ang ganitong mga klaseng plot na nagtatackle ng political issues ng bansa. very very very kaya! she has a lot to offer, she can be more kaya sana pagbigyan siya especially wala na 'yong pabigat niyang duo. and i think sobrang laking impact niya kasi ang lawak ng sakop ni kathryn sa mainstream.could've been the best Best BEST so far pero it's a great stepping stone for kathryn as an actress (like ..outside romance genres gets b huhu) and finally nakawala na siya sa walang katapusang movies na iisa lang ang partner niya, iba-iba lang ang takbo ng kwento. konting push pa! more movies for her please na iba-iba ang genre!! let her explore!!and for alden, bigyan lang 'to ng maayos na script and a character na very fitting sa kaniyang genre (romcom, slice of life). i believe he can boost his potential from there. super super super kaya niya, this movie proves that! pero creepy talaga si ethan huhu if that's what his character wants to tell us then wtf he's so effective :D

"Ang laki ng mundo, natatakot ako.""Kaya mo yan." - i cried again for the third time - pucha, favorite ko atang contemporary Filipino movie to?- hindi ako pala-rewatch ng shows kasi i lose interest pag alam ko na ung plot, or dapat may 5+ years interval para ma-appreciate ko siya ulet, but not this film haha- first Kathryn Bernardo film i watched in full, nakikita ko lang kasi movies niya sa Cinema One then hindi ko naman pinapanood. When HLG came out, very intrigued talaga ako kasi new pairing tapos from 2 rival networks pa, and may reputation naman sila both na magaling umarte. o diba, macu-curious ka talaga, and IT DID NOT DISAPPOINT- kathryn carried the film, bukod sa magaling siya umarte, maganda ang character ni Joy, madaming pinaghuhugutan. Alden gave the right amount of effort in what was required from his character.- nakakakilig sila  lalo na ung piggyback ride scene, idk ang cute nila don- napansin ko ngayon, na-bother ako slight sa mga ayos-sombrero acting ni pareng Alden, mejo naparami- as usual dapat may mga side characters na friends na fun, fun lang. sisingit ng mga light, corny lines in support to main characters haha pero tamang cast naman ung side characters nila dito

watched this the first time and i didnt really like it. but now that i watched it again, i understood why this is the highest grossing filipino film. it captured the hardships and realities of what DH Filipinos experience on a subtly deep level. the longing for ‘more’ but you have to remain in that level just because there is a need to provide. tbh, ethan and joy’s love story was not the main point of this movie; it was more of a side story that helped resurface joy’s character of resilience and strength. those characteristics were used by ethan as a stepping stool not to use it against her but to help her. yes, there were some misdirects esp when ethan didnt want joy to leave and didnt understand her situation at first. it was extremely notable how he didnt force her even though he knows he soon can provide and actually just gave her the best possible 3D2N ‘tour’ joy could bring as a memory before she departs. i love that he didnt stray her away from her independence. it couldve went to a whole diff direction where they built a life in HK but, direk cathy made it a point to make sure that the viewers heard and saw what she wanted the movie to focus on. not ur typical love story, so impactful and so realistic esp to filipinos.

Wonderful story, impeccable acting and glorious chemistry by both leads, beautifully directed and beautifully shot, this movie is truly a work of art. And with such compelling characters and story, no wonder there is a sequel already.

Unexpectedly a success film in every aspect! The story was superb and well-written! It is so relatable by giving highlight to the plight of our Filipino OFWs in Hong Kong with a twist of romance that is far from montage of chessy lines and scenes. Given with this plot about OFW, it is so relevant and relatable already to the audiences. The lead characters shone on their own equally in the story the same as the lead casts justified their roles in giving a compelling performances that exceeds expectations. This is a proof that you don't need love team tandems to produce a great movie! Even the supporting casts, they gave so much life to the story of this movie. And they gave intermittent breaks from the seriousness of the main story. Hong Kong chosen as a backdrop setting for the entire film was promoted fully here and went beyond by showing to us the OFW daily life of Filipinos there. This is a certified travel movie as well! The shots in Hong Kong and its places were flawless and stunning! I love that they promoted it not just a "transit" place which Hong Kong is used to be known but also a place to stay. Cinematography was commendable. This film was actually close to masterpiece if it weren't for a open-ended ending that I felt and the rest of the audiences were left wanting more. This is highly recommended!

The movie offers to mainstream America a compelling, detailed, compassionate look at the little-known lives, and hopes, of domestic workers.
